summary: Will Hunting (Matt Damon) has a genius-level IQ but chooses to work as a janitor at MIT. When he solves a difficult graduate-level math problem, his talents are discovered by Professor Gerald Lambeau (Stellan Skarsgard), who decides to help the misguided youth reach his potential. When Will is arrested for attacking a police officer, Professor Lambeau makes a deal to get leniency for him if he will get treatment from therapist Sean Maguire (Robin Williams).

reviews.content: One of the top 20 movies of all time. Williams is spectacular.
average movie and only the ending was emotional and performed well by the actors

Will Hunting is a young man who has been blessed with an incredible talent. Unfortunately he was also cursed with a terrible upbringing. He was a foster child that went through many abusive foster families before living on his own. This has left many scars not only on his body but also in his heart. This prevents him from moving forward through life and fulfilling his potential. This would all change after one fateful encounter...

Camerawork was nothing to write home about but not the worst either. The music in this movie was absolutely perfect, loved it very much. In general this movie is one of my favorites of all time. So with a little bias sprinkled on top I will give this movie a perfect score.

"Good Will Hunting" (1997) is a drama/romance film that explores the life and struggles of Will Hunting (played by Matt Damon), a young man from a working-class background who has a prodigious talent for mathematics. Directed by Gus Van Sant and written by Damon and Ben Affleck, the film follows Will as he navigates his relationships with his friends, his love interest (played by Minnie Driver), and a therapist (played by Robin Williams) who helps him to confront his personal demons.

The film's strongest aspect is its writing, with Damon and Affleck delivering a powerful and emotional script that explores themes of identity, relationships, and personal growth. The film's characters are well-written and well-acted, with Damon delivering a standout performance as Will Hunting. Williams also delivers an excellent performance as Will's therapist, earning an Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor.

The film's cinematography is solid and effective, capturing the gritty and realist aesthetic of the film's working-class setting. The film's music, composed by Danny Elfman, is subtle and effective, enhancing the film's emotional moments without overwhelming them. The film's direction by Van Sant is confident and assured, delivering a visual style that is both effective and understated.

However, some may argue that the film's pace is slow at times, lacking the dramatic momentum of other dramas. Additionally, some may find the film's resolution to be too neat and tidy, failing to fully explore the complexities of Will's personal struggles.

Overall, "Good Will Hunting" is a well-made and emotionally powerful drama/romance film that explores themes of identity, relationships, and personal growth with intelligence and empathy. With strong writing, excellent performances, and confident direction, "Good Will Hunting" is a movie that will appeal to fans of drama, romance, and thought-provoking filmmaking.

"Good Will Hunting" is a 1997 film directed by Gus Van Sant and written by Ben Affleck and Matt Damon. The film stars Matt as Will Hunting, a young man from South Boston with a troubled past who works as a janitor at MIT (Massachusetts Institute of Technology). 

Despite lacking former education, Will is able to solve a mathematics problem which was supposed to be very advanced for the actual students, revealing that the protagonist actually has an overwhelming talent for mathematics. When a renowned mathematician (played by Stellan Skarsgård) discovers Will's abilities, he sets out to help him reach his full potential. The story goes on when, due to unforeseen circumstances, Will has to attend a psychologist called Sean (Robin Williams), and also finds the person who could be the love of his life.

This film enters typical topics such as love and friendship, but also enters in the world of denial and struggle to find one's place in the world. The performance by all the main actors (Damon, Affleck and Williams) are outstanding, and the film's script is moving and insightful. Even if Good Will Hunting is a movie over 20 years old, it still remains an emotional and impactful movie.

Whilst I understand the concept, the underdog hides a genius trait that is juxtaposed against his obvious flaws and spotted by a near-genius who wishes to uncover the diamond in the rough this film for me falls short of entertainment. If it truly followed through as a feel-good winner story that had us rooting for the main character then I would have enjoyed the ride however this film plays on uncomfortable moments to create tension which in my opinion stands in the way of making this enjoyable viewing. The whole relationship angle that our genius becomes involved in is an aside as is the strangled attempts to clean him up via therapy. We get a lot of impressions within the movie but nothing really sticks. As usual, Willams overshadows the entire cast but even then I feel he is acting alone in a movie that is indifferent to talent and simply tells the story of a clever guy who has been overlooked. And to be honest that is a story that does not really need to be told. What a bore.
Great performances. Drawn out but still a good watch

The late Robin Williams, Matt Damon, Minnie Driver, and Ben Affleck directed by Gus Van Sant This is one of the best dramas I've watched with one of my favorite ensemble casts The story centers on a youth named Will Hunting; he has an IQ that's outstanding but his life growing up in the Boston area always hit a curveball getting involved in street fights, grand theft auto, getting arrested etc. as well as going through several foster homes Plus the only job he has at the moment is the janitor at MIT Will solved a math problem on the hallway chalkboard part of a student challenge – whoever solves it will have their name immortalised in the university’s newspaper The math professor who discovers his genius decides to give him an opportunity to utilize his talents and teach him mathematical equations to avoid jail time and in turn Will also goes to see a therapist named Maguire In a way Maguire is, like Will, a Southie native of working-class background, a Vietnam veteran still mourning his late wife The sessions are tough but Will and Sean start opening up more about themselves than they anticipated, maybe over time Will can discover that deep down he is too 'good' for his own good It doesn't all have to be self-sabotage Will also starts dating a Harvard law student named Skyler and she along with everyone starts to see more than a photographic memory but as more grounded with flaws and a vulnerability that will win over even the hardest of hearts The movie succeeds so well due to a lively screenplay and fine performances all around, and it consistently delivers emotional payoffs Damon is sensational and this is one of the most multifaceted performances of Williams' career The viewer understands Hunting’s bitterness and pain hiding behind his witty persona They can also appreciate Williams’ healing through humour, a bittersweet observation There is a lot that grounds the film in the ’90s, starting with the ever-present fear of “selling out,” as well as a monologue from Will about geopolitics that seems straight from the work of Noam Chomsky It helps too this refreshingly celebrated being bright – at a time in a when the dumbing down of America had been reflected in its cinematic fare An outstanding movie after 25 years with solid performances and a compelling story but also very earned emotions A simple work of art that still speaks to the heart with a good amount of psychological drama Something that explores the human condition as it reacts to emotional and psychological issues should always be highly valued It also celebrates knowledge and emotion, showing how both can bring downfalls but can be powerful tools; its emphasis on psychology, trauma, emotion, and bonds will always be relevant

Yes, Good Will Hunting is predictable and offers a simple narrative, but man does it pack in a great and emotionally-layered script with some great performances from it's cast, specifically Damon and Williams, and really touches you. The film delves into the psychology behind it's protagonist as well as the actual psychologist (played by Robin Williams) and is an emotional look back at what has made them who they currently are as people. The film is easy to fall into and the story so emotionally involving on the part of the viewer that the two hours flies by.

This film speaks to a special part of me. Coming from a similar background as Will on the opposite side of the country in a little corner of Los Angeles, I think I look at him and get scared because I see myself in him. Not at the same level of intelligence, but on a uniquely similar wavelength. Friends who don't come from much but would still take a bullet for me, a hard upbringing coupled with an extreme aversion to rules and attachment, would, I'd say make me a prime candidate for a conscious comparison. Wouldn't look at a guy like me and think much of anything besides "I might take him back to my house for the night. MIGHT." Wouldn't think I tested college level for my writing ability in the third grade, or that I know more about stock options than I do shapes. But therein lays the beauty of the chord that this film plucks on time and time again. I can't watch this film without being on the verge of tears because Will Hunting is painfully real. All the kid ever wanted was to feel like he belonged. Like someone cared. And no one ever did until he met Skylar. That's where this film gets it right. Nothing will ever change a man's life more than the loving touch of a woman. I only wish I didn't push the Skylar I knew away. Because I know she's not coming back. He didn't have that burden.

Good Will Hunting is a beautifully filmed movie with striking scenery, and it is directed wonderfully by Van Sant. The music is never obtrusive but never too low-key either, while the story is interesting and compelling and the script intelligently written.

The acting is one of the film's best assets, as well as its compellingly real characters. Robin Williams is superb in one of his best "drama" roles, while Ben Affleck has never been better and Matt Damon gives another fine performance to match his performance in The Talented Mr Ripley. Minnie Driver is also quite touching and believable.

All in all, an incredible movie. 10/10 Bethany Cox

It does everything it can to convince us that he is a good guy but fails to answer a straightforward question: does he EVER actually resolve his egotistical, asshole behavior? For this reason, I found that Matt Damon's character, while tragic, gets less interesting and less sympathetic as the movie goes on.

It's sad to see what happened to Minnie Driver in the making of this movie by the producer, but it doesn't take away from her brilliant performance in this film. Robin Williams is top-notch as the therapist that can relate to Hunting's Southy upbringing and abusive parents. Damon and Affleck shine through in this big hit. For any writer this movie would be absolutely amazing work, but for 2 first-timers, this is legendary work.

"Good Will Hunting" is a movie not like any other. Out of all the movies I've ever seen, This is the most true and realistic movie that exists. This is partly because the movie is one big character study. Both Matt Damon's character and Robin Williams"s character have so much revealed about them and their conversations with eachother  make them feel so real. But it's not just the main characters that are handled so well, even all the side characters had amazing arcs that made me care for them. The characterization is this movie is done so perfectly because this has one of the best screen plays of all time. The back and fourth between two characters and also the monolagues different characters had were moving, intriguing, and interesting. From symbolism to Foreshadowing the poetic tone that every word held brought a breath of fresh air into this movie. But what would be the point of good writing if there were no good actors? Wouldn't that just make the screen play become a cheesy mess? Well everyone in this stellar cast made it very clear through their performances that they really cared about the characters. They put so much effort into their characters making the script shine the brightest it possibly could. This movie isn't just a movie, but it is a poem.

An absolute gem of a film. The relationship between Robin Williams' Sean and Matt Damon's Will is one of the most beautiful put to film. We begin with a prodigiously intelligent young man hellbent on avoiding vulnerability by drinking around with his boys. And we watch as the shields he's built are slowly peeled back, the crippling trauma of the abuse he's endured is eased, and the risk-laden joys of intimate relationships are embraced. "It's not your fault," is so powerful.

There is clearly a mix of glowing and scathing reviews here, so I might as well put my two cents in. So what do I think of it? The concept did not really ring true.

The protagonist is an undiscovered genius who is able to figure out things that stump even the geniuses, such as a complicated mathematical problem, even though he works as a college janitor. He has a poor background and emotional problems from a bad childhood, plus a girl interested in him, yet instead of breaking out of his miserable existence he initially wants to stay in it...but is convinced to change his mind.

So what went wrong? A genius might have a rough existence, but he acts like everybody else around him except for his magically solving complicated mathematical problems. Um, anyone who's so much smarter than his peers would show signs of it that nobody could ignore, such as being able to say and do things most others wouldn't think of. Why couldn't he have become, say, a professional gambler (degree not required)? Why would he cause trouble and not be able to charm his way out of it. Will Hunting is a genius and does not behave like a genius in real life would, no matter his background. That spoils the movie for me.

This movie is about potential. About not so much meeting your potential but reaching for it. That's what I found to be the best part of this movie. About a man sitting on a goldmine but he's to scared to reach out and cash it in. The back and forth between Will and Sean, the confrontations with Skyler and Lambeau, the casual heart to heart of two buddies taking a break at work. The satisfying moments of Will's intellectual triumph's revealed to mean nothing to him, boring to him. All of this real, human drama asks the question of what potential is, what purpose is. Unlike so many films that use ambiguity as a pedestal for creating more evocative work, Good Will Hunting gives a quiet, thoughtful answer to the question it asks and says if you want to reach your potential you have to get off your butt and do something, get out of your comfort zone. Will's intellectual capabilities were only part of the picture and from a storytelling perspective, just a larger than life ingredient to drive home the message of the question "what do you want to do?" I think when Sean asks that question is when Will's world suddenly falls. Suddenly it's not about living up to other peoples expectations, it's about living up to your own, about having the drive to do something more. With Skyler to get him thinking, Sean to get him talking and the last push from Chuckie to get him moving, Will is faced with his whole life and finally knows what he'll do with it. That's a powerful message and one made ever so poignant by the eloquence of the dialogue (punctuated... ahem, ever so delicately by the... ahem, colorful language) that often plays out like a battle of wits that's a pleasure to witness, the strength, the depth of emotion, the genuine feeling of each performance (especially from the great Robin Williams), the slices of goofing around, telling stories, talking about nothing gives out a feel good spirit to a movie with a message that should be hard to swallow. Not only is that good stuff, that's important stuff, especially for me, That's almost definitely the reason I'm giving this movie such a high rating. The core of it connected with me in a very special way but it's not bias, it's just what art does to you.

This movie is like a cure for depression. We are, at some level, different Will Huntings following the flow of life, and sometimes we lose meaning in our lives. We follow the life patterns offered to us by the people around us. When I feel anything like this, I revisit this movie again to battle with those emotions. Every time, the movie is as effective as the first time. Especially the scenes with Robin Williams are unforgettable due to both transfer of the emotions and the sentences in the dialogue. The dialogue was really captivating , thought provoking and striking. Must watch!!

Gus Van Sant is guilty of producing some absolute drivel during his career (his Pyscho remake is sacrilege) but this is arguably his best work. Helped by an Oscar winning script by Matt Damon and Ben Affleck, the film follows a troubled maths genius, who prefers to work as a janitor and lead a normal life than to use his gift. Eventually, a university professor persuades him to see a psychologist, played brilliantly by Robin Williams (an Oscar win for him too) who helps him come to terms with his talent, as well as helping him to tackle his past trauma. A classic.

In Gus Van Sant's first significant foray into mainstream Hollywood filmmaking, Good Will Hunting proves that he is able to show that his focus is still primarily the humanity of his characters.  With a sharp script by Ben Affleck and Matt Damon, the movie is filled with plenty of meaningful dialogue and impactful scenes, but where Van Sant excels is in those quiet moments where he allows the camera to linger on mournful eyes or a hopeful facial expression to tell his story.  Despite its predictable plot, it's a moving and impactful tale of young man overcoming crushing adversity to find his way in life and, thanks in part to great performances, is well worth the time invested.
"Good Will Hunting" is everything I hoped it would be: smart, original, mature, terrifically paced and perfectly acted. This is without a doubt - a masterpiece!
A beautiful story. Would recommend.

the film managed to make me feel very emotional about the characters, even some time after watching. while the plot is by no mean very special or interesting and filled with clichés the dialogues are absolutely amazing and the way the relationships develop was incredible. robbin williams and matt damon really shine and are - together with the other actors - what makes the movie so special. it's the characters and the relationships they have together. i am amazed and wonder how they managed to make me root for will & skylar.
the songs by elliot smith also help by creating an atmosphere of nostalgic optimism & help create a deep, unknown grief for the things i didn't do because i was too afraid to open my heart up to & allow myself to be vulnerable i feel after watching.
i also liked the strong use of the colors red & blue.

An emotionally engaging drama that's sprinkled with well-timed comedy and brilliantly crafted dialogue. Robin Williams is amazing and Matt Damon is quite impressive with his emotional range considering how early he was in his career at this point. I love the themes about life, personal relationships, careers, and the deep personal impacts of childhood trauma. My only glaring issue with the movie is how cruel and borderline abusive Matt Damon's character gets towards his girlfriend towards the end of the movie and just how nonchalantly glossed over it was by the movie and the other characters. They treated it more like a disappointing break-up than a yellow flag of the possibility of continuing the cycle of abuse onto his loved ones. Which is a damn shame since it could've been a really powerful moment that would've shed some nuance on the dangers of lashing out at your loved ones as a means of coping with your own trauma and how we can choose the higher path. It could've done a better job at highlighting the consequences of lashing out and the path to personal redemption. I'll also admit that the protagonist is a bit grating early on as the unrealistically brilliant and douchey jerk-sue character, a common power fantasy enjoyed by male screenwriters and moviegoers alike. But flaws aside, this is still an emotionally moving movie that's definitely worth a watch.

I think one of my favorite things to have happened in Hollywood is that Matt Damon, destined to be a movie star for his looks & acting ability, achieved stardom from a movie whose Oscar-winning screenplay he wrote. The characters were well-designed and the scenes with his therapist were effective at eliciting emotion. I wasn't fully on board with the initial fighting scenes as the fact they were written by testosterone-filled 20-somethings shone through in them but they otherwise did an impeccable job. The acting was obviously top-notch and the really seemed to make their $10M budget stretch with well-designed sets.

With an incredible story, great dialogue, and perfect acting, "Good Will Hunting" is one of the best dramas in film history. The script is amazing, and what makes it more impressive is that Matt Damon and Ben Affleck wrote it at the young ages of twenty-seven and twenty-five. What makes the dialogue so great is characters tell stories, which is how people actually connect and communicate. The acting is truly remarkable. Matt Damon, Ben Affleck, Minnie Driver, and Stellan Skarsgård give stellar performances. Robin Williams in this movie is arguably the best part of this movie. The legendary actor brings a very compelling character to life in a way no one else can come close to. This movie gets me emotional every time. Good Will Hunting is to me a film of authentic experience. The soul of this movie is undoubtedly Robin Williams and his powerful ability to portrait genuine compassion woven with pain and hurt. Matt Damon is also no slouch in that department. That sentiment and barriers we all face accessing that virtue is the core of this movie. The narrative is pretty standard: someone greater than their class and start held back by the legacy of that life trying to find a way out. All the usual stages of psychological development play out: denial, anger, bargaining, depression and eventual acceptance of life's trauma. The formula isn't this story's big hook. It is how the characters manage to feel so real. 

Everyone in this movie shows moments of honesty, failure and humanity. They all do it in ways that remain true to the characters they're cast as. This is not all moments of feel good triumph or acceptance, but people growing struggling and advancing with the materials put in front of them. I cannot think of a more satisfying way to tell this type of story.

Good Will Hunting is such a brilliant movie and it's especially a masterpiece and a half. The movie's got such an amazing story and it's about this lad who's called Will Hunting (Matt Damon), who's this very intelligent genius at mathematics and he's really good at solving all the difficult mathematical problems.

However, when he starts to face an emotional crisis, he starts to see many different psychiatrist's until he finds the right one who can help him and his name is Dr Sean Maguireto (Robin Williams), who later helps Will recover.

The movie's got some amazing performance's from all of the cast, especially from Will (Matt Damon) and Sean (Robin Williams), those two are honestly brilliant and the two of them bring their characters to life so well.

The dialogue which is given and received from each character throughout this movie is all very strong dialogue. The dialogue which this movie's got never feels weak at any moment and every single bit of the dialogue comes out very strong.

The movie's cinematographer Jean-Yves Esoffier does such a beautiful job on capturing each moment and each emotion from each character so beautifully, he honestly does it so well.

Also, the chemistry between Matt Damon and Robin Williams throughout this movie is honestly great and it adds so much to their friendship in this movie and it works perfectly.

The pacing in this movie is honestly great, each main moment which ends up happening throughout this movie is all well built up and it's so beautifully well done.

The movie's even got some brilliant humour, which is well scattered throughout and all of the humour works very well in making me laugh in some sort of way.

Finally, the movie's got some really great emotions and they're all well built up with the great pacing and it really adds to their characters as a whole throughout this movie.

The movie's even got some brilliant character development with the main character Will, It's so beautifully well done and it works so perfectly due to the events, which end up happening to him.

The love interest in this movie, which is between Will and Skylar (Minnie Driver) is so beautifully well done and the certain events, which end up happening throughout their relationship are all well built up.

Overall, Good Will Hunting is such a brilliant movie with such an amazing story, amazing performances, very strong dialogue, beautiful cinematography, great chemistry, great pacing, brilliant humour, great emotions, brilliant character development and such a beautiful love interest.

I'd honestly recommend Good Will Hunting, if you're wanting to watch a very beautiful Drama/Romance movie. It's honestly worth the watch, it's so amazing.

Good Will Hunting, originated by Matt Damon is such a well thought out, catharsis-driven film, that has countless acts of accurate psychological motions, according to the novel Into the Woods. In Harvard, Matt Damon was assigned to write a final act for his film class, but ended up writting a 40 page script, originating Good Will Hunting. Gus Van Sant took on the directors chair, having a reputation of creating just average movies. Gus Van Sant, Matt Damon & Ben Affleck worked tirelessly together, to put on such an inspiring movie.

This story may have came off a tad predictable throughout, but the narrative packed deep messages, involving all the characters as much as possible. With all the messages of friendship, acceptance, and self realization, Vant Sant, Damon & Affleck kept this lazer-focused structure, paying close attention to detail.

The screenplay by Ben Afleck & Matt Damon was written & portrayed at such a prestigious level, being so memorable! My one question is, HOW DID THIS NOT GET THE COMEDY GENRE TITLE?! I found this movie absolutely hilarious through the first two acts! The jokes hit every single time, due to the terrific chemistry the whole cast has. With the absolute brilliant script, Matt Damon & Ben Affleck were awarded by the Academy Awards for Best Original Script.

Billy Hopkins, Kerry Barden & Suzanne Smith casted such a brilliantly talented cast, that had effortless chemistry. Matt Damon put on, in my opinion, his best performance, and I'm still very upset he didn't win the Oscar for Best Actor. His performance was super intelligent, while also having so many different enjoyable character traits. Right off the bat, you really felt for his character. His backstory is what holds him back in life, playing himself as his own antagonist, so it was a breeze to indulge into his character, despite his unorthodox personality. Ben Affleck put on such an authentic performance. The connection Affleck & Damon have off the screen really shows on set, being cut from the same cloth, along with Casey Affleck, Cole Hauser & John Mighton. Right along with Matt Damon, I'd personally say that this is my favorite Robin Williams performance. You can sense his wit & mature mindset the minute he steps foot on set. The bond he creates with Matt Damon is nothing short of inspiring, while having one of the best scenes in cinema history. His performance felt so genuine & connective, it won him an Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor. Minnie Driver was a constant presence throughout the film, aiding Damon's character development. She was also another character you can truly feel for. Her expressions and feelings were sold great, feeling like Damon & Driver have done more than one movie together. Stellan Skarsgard was a big part of how everything moved. He also had a great connection with Robin Williams, having one specific scene feeling so real! The Boston accents everyone had were actually awesome! Everyone who had the accent, felt so authentic, flowing great with the theme and setting.

Overall, after only seeing this movie once, it ranks up in my personal favorite top ten list.

Good Will Hunting is a very heartfelt movie written and starring Ben Affleck and Matt Damon, with Robin Williams who gives a truly oscar worthy performance. Gus Van Zant's indie coming of age drama Good Will Hunting (1997) is phenomenal. It's still as affecting now that I'm grown up as when I was an impressionable kid watching this film. Gus van Zant's direction is intimate and heartfelt as he casually captures genuine moments of friendship, romance, and therapy with a gentle eye for serene mid shots. His use of close-ups is particularly riveting and emotional in Good Will Hunting. Van Zant's indie sensibilities ensure his artistic vision is realized in a sincere way full of fragile sentimental characters that reflect regular guys. You can tell Van Zant is an indie auteur as he even has underground director Harmony Korine cameo as a crazy criminal named Jerve.

Matt Damon is astounding as the complex teenage savant Will Hunting. He explodes with visceral rage, defensive angst, endearing romance, cruel lies, endless deceit, broken tears, and peerless academic knowledge. Damon convinces you his character Will is both troubled and genius. He feels effortless in the role, but you can tell Damon poured his heart and soul into this magnificent character acting. I would even say Will Hunting is his best character up there with Jason Bourne. Damon is not always a subtle actor, but his expressive acting is full of energy and passion.

Robin Williams is sublime as Sean Maguire. His bearded, patient, and sensitive therapist professor is such a wonderful display of Williams' dramatic prowess as an actor. He demonstrates how deep he can make a man with his nuanced and devastating dramatic character acting. Williams uses his immense heart to make Maguire inspiring, relatable, and real. He delivers several incredible speeches and lines that stay with you forever after seeing Good Will Hunting.

Stellan Skarsgård is excellent as the driven, genius mathematics professor Gerald Lambeau pushing Damon towards a theoretical mathematics profession. Ben Affleck makes a turn as a nice loyal friend to Damon named Chuckie Sullivan. His earnest admission about his desire for Will's future at the construction site is so powerful and real, especially with the payoff at Will's house at the end. Good Will Hunting is some of Ben Affleck's finest dramatic acting. Casey Affleck is hilarious as the Boston lowlife Morgan O'Mally. His casual remarks come across as really sincere, so he's an endearing idiot. I love his one liner after Damon stands up for Ben Affleck against a pseudo-intellectual college student. Minnie Driver is profoundly moving as Damon's girlfriend Skylar. Her tears in her dorm room feel so authentic to her character's heartbreak.

Good Will Hunting is simply a life changing, life affirming, and inspiring film that holds up beautifully. Van Zant desperately searches for human decency and kindness in his seminal drama. You will find purpose in life after watching this moving drama that is so very down to Earth. Good Will Hunting is one of those rare films that everyone I know loves dearly.

Matt Damon and Ben Affleck's script is raw, real, and thoughtful as these two teenage actors wrote an original screenplay with a Boston realism and a sympathetic viewpoint. They take on child abuse, career potential, lifelong friendship, new romance, spousal grief, patient therapy, and emotional honesty in this mature script full of heart. How can you not be impressed by the monologues and little details in Good Will Hunting?

Pietro Scalia's editing is very slick as he cuts from quiet scenes of reflection to noisy conversations that friends have to randomly goof around. Scalia's editing choices make Good Will Hunting's 127 minutes to fly by like a quick afternoon. Jean-Yves Escoffier's cinematography delivers soft close-ups indoors during therapy sessions that hit hard, while outdoors there are such warm tones and cute framing. His shots are now classic and remain timeless by their own virtues. He captures real feeling with his emotionally gripping shot choices. I love the medium shots of Casey Affleck or Matt Damon looking out a window while Ben Affleck drives them around Boston.

Danny Elfman's sweet score is a symphony to sympathy. His caring melodies cradle the painful moments of touching drama within Good Will Hunting like a warm blanket. Beatrix Aruna Pasztor's costumes look well worn and realistic to the era and location. I love her cardigan sweaters for Robin Williams or her scarf choice for Stellan Skarsgård. Missy Stewart and James McAteer's production design displays impoverished Boston homes that look like lived in shacks, while coming up with sleek and authentic feeling offices for the two university professors' offices.

In all, Gus Van Zant directed an iconic film for all audiences that teenagers and adults alike can enjoy.

SYNOPSIS:
Will Hunting (Matt Damon) seems to have everything you'd want from unparalleled intelligence to incredibly loyal friends to the most loving girlfriend, but even with all of this Will still keeps a wall between him and everything he cares about. A life that would appear to be so simple, is in fact a lot more complex than it seems.

DIRECTION:
Gus Van Sant directs this thing to near perfection. Through his direction there is so much life and grounding added to a story that otherwise seems quite plain. Knowing at which points to change the focus of the camera from one character to the next. Knowing when to hold a close up to really cease a beautiful scene and capture the expression. Now, I'm not going to sit here and act like no one else could've directed this film, however, a film like this could've easily been ruined by poor directing and editing. Great work.

WRITING:
Matt Damon and Ben Affleck really knocked this one out of the park. Not only was both of their acting on-point, but the dialogue in the film is so pure. There are so many memorable moments in this film just from incredible dialogue. It feels as if there's not a single line in this film that goes unnoticed or should be cut. If the heart could write a script I'm pretty sure this screenplay is what would be the result. This film definitely deserved the Best Original Screenplay Oscar that it won.

ACTING:
It's not your fault. It's not your fault. I swear Robin Williams had me screaming "I KNOW, SEAN!" followed by aggressive tears from the guilt I felt that I never actually had a reason to feel, but damn you Robin Williams. On top of that, Matt Damon, how dare you memorize ridiculously intellectual monologues like the one at the Harvard Bar scene and the one that cut from you being at a job interview with the CIA or whoever to you being seated in Sean's office. I'm starting to feel this is an autobiography. Are those just books? I don't know. Shut up. Then moving on the Ben Affleck who is my dream best friend. One I can confide in and a man who will willingly go to my job interviews in an over-dramatic BAHSTON accent acting as a pretentious douche. Yes, please! Minnie Driver. That heartbreaking scene over the phone... "I love you." Say it back... SAY IT BACK, WILL! What a killer Irish accent by the way. Not an Irish bone in my body, but trust me... killed that accent. Stellan Skarsgard, I understand how much you care for him Stellan, but he doesn't want to be a damn mathematician. Do you know how easy it is for him?! DO YOU? And Casey Affleck, stop worrying about your damn double burger. I do have to acknowledge how resourceful you were with that baseball glove though. *Tips the hat* 
I realize I just pretty much reiterated lines from the film, but the acting is so damn good that I don't even know what else to say. It's so amazing. I will say this film does possibly have the worst performance of anyone ever, however. Professor Lambeau's assistant. He looked and sounded like he was continuously trying to put himself asleep during every scene he's in.

CONCLUSION:
This is my favorite film of all time. Though the directing is anything to go crazy about, the writing and the acting in this film, elevates this film to an entire different dimension for me. I can watch this film on repeat 24 hours a day. Actually, make that like 16. Sleep is essential to get another productive 16 hours of Good Will Hunting. That's my review.

Good Will Hunting is a very simplistic movie. I believe in the time that it came out, it would've have  been seen as a great movie but by now it's more of a clichÃ (C). The introduction of a secret genius hidden amongst a small group of delinquents eventually became convoluted with the presence of immense emotional blockage. At some points, the movie doesn't even seem to follow a simple plot and is more of a timespan of the boy's day to day. The scenes just transfer from spending time with his friends, to his girlfriend, to his professor, to being at work, and to his therapist. Of course, all these events round up to the final singularity near the end of the movie. All in all, it was too realistic, which made it rather boring.

Van Sant's coaching is pretty much what you already know. His guidance isn't extraordinary but is undeniably productive. This vivacious film runs on nothing but the merit of the script. Matt Damon and Ben Affleck, the writers, aren't bringing anything new on the table, but it is the Disney of the dramatic movies. Incredibly confident in its ingredients, the film never stutters, not even for a frame. What's been so crowd pleasing about the script, is its ability to create a topsy-turvy world in a pragmatic one. Usually, the concept of "power" in the hand is often presented as misused by the characters and also always is craved by them.

In here, Matt Damon who powerfully portrays a guy that accounts in, his photographic memory as a hindrance. His surrounding doesn't ask him to repel it, but his affection towards that very surrounding and the fear to go physically distant with it, makes him turn all this into a hobby. Damon's excruciating performance of an arrogant and blessed kid has a match that makes him rubble in a snap.

And the answer is Robin Williams, that cloaks in a completely opposite persona to Damon in order to get in, in his game. If Damon likes to hurt, he keeps his wound open, if Damon oozes power and rage, he whispers warmth so gently that it makes your eyes teary within a blink. And despite of all the other tracks sprinkled amazingly in the film, Williams and Damon sharing a few laughs sitting in the room is the best asset of it, that Gus Van Sant is well aware of and encourages it like some big antic to stand tall and proud upon. Good Will Hunting is never a hunt, if anything it is the surrender in a long lasting lost game, that actually our host never cares for.

Matt Damon and Ben Affleck won the Oscar for best original screenplay and effectively launched their careers as stars with this film, directed by Gus Van Sant (best known then for Drugstore Cowboy, My Own Private Idaho, and To Die For).  When Van Sant came on board, Robin Williams (already a superstar) signed up.  I skipped this in the 1990s but I thought I would fill in this gap now.  Damon plays a kid from Boston who has genius-level math ability but is self-taught and full of anger and defensiveness.  When he is discovered/rescued by a math professor (Stellan SkarsgÃ¥rd), the deal is that he can stay out of jail only if he attends both math workshops and therapy.  No therapist can handle his challenges until Sean Maguire (Robin Williams), also from working class South Boston and the professorâ(TM)s former college roommate, is brought in.  At the same time, Will Hunting (Damon) continues to hang out with his school mates, the two Afflecks included, and while at a bar, he meets Skylar (Minnie Driver, in a charismatic performance) and they start a romance.  Willâ(TM)s avoidant attachment style (developed through harsh treatment at the orphanage where he grew up) nearly causes him to throw away his career in maths and his new romance with Skylar.  Of course, with the loving mentoring of Williams (underplaying dramatically), he breaks through the wall. In a movie like this, it isnâ(TM)t a spoiler, is it?  This is all about the final âfeel goodâ? moment â" which also reduces the filmâ(TM)s artistic merits (i.e., its been given the Hollywood treatment which you can see coming from a mile away).  The psychologizing is probably a bit too pat as well. That said, there are many finely observed moments in the film and the actors work hard to give their characters some depth (even if not everyone can pull off the Boston accent). At the end of the day, it is probably a testament to Van Santâ(TM)s skill that this came off as well as it did; in the hands of a lesser director it could have been much soppier stuff.

Good Will Hunting is a 1997 drama that made 225.9 million dollars in box office earnings. It follows the story of Will Hunting, a 20 year old genius working as a janitor at MIT. While all his friends want him to do something with his life, he wants to stay where he is. After Will solves a graduate level math problem, Professor Gerald Lambeau is impressed with him, but Will soon gets arrested. Professor Lambeau makes a deal to keep Will out of jail, he has to study math with him and go to therapy once a week. Will refuses to take the therapy sessions seriously and multiple therapists refuse to talk to him again after only one session. Lambeau eventually goes to his former college roommate, Dr. Sean Maguire. Dr. Maguire gets Will to open up to him and helps him overcome his past and find what he wants. The purpose of the movie Good Will Hunting is to show that you only regret the chances you didn't take. I will show the purpose through plot, character, and conflict. 
You only regret the chances you didn't take. That's how Dr. Sean Maguire feels about missing one of the greatest games in baseball history "to see about a girl." After will asks him if he really missed game six of the World Series to have a drink with a girl, he tells him, "I don't regret the 18 years I was married to Nancy. I don't regret the six years I had to give up counseling when she got sick. And I don't regret the last years when she got really sick. And I sure as hell don't regret missin' the damn game. That's regret." 
Throughout the film, Will's friends all want him to go to school, get a job, and do something with his life. Especially his best friend Chuckie. Every morning Chuckie hopes that Will's not home, that he finally left. He tells Will "Look, you're my best friend, so don't take this the wrong way. In twenty years, if you're still livin' here, comin' over to my house to watch the Patriots games, still workin' construction, I'll fuckin' kill you." "Hanging around here is a fuckin' waste of your time." He knows that Will is too smart to waste his life working construction when he could have an amazing job. Any one of their friends would kill for the opportunities Will has, yet he does nothing.
The main antagonist in Good Will Hunting is Will. The only thing holding him back from going to school and getting an amazing job is himself. When Professor Lambeau tells him he can be released as long as he does math and goes to therapy, Will laughs. He agrees to do the math but refuses to go to therapy. When he eventually gives in, he still doesn't take the therapy sessions seriously. He thinks he'll be happy where he is even though his friends know he's going to regret it eventually. After he talks to Dr. Maguire he realizes he needs to take the opportunity he's given.
Some people say that the theme of Good Will Hunting is education, but that's only part of it. Yes Will needed to go to school, but he also needed the therapy sessions. Skylar was also a big part of the movie. Will needed the therapy sessions and Skylar to realize what he would be missing if he didn't take the opportunity. It wasn't just about school.
Good Will Hunting was successful in showing the theme of regretting chances you never took. It was shown through Dr. Sean Maguire's character and throughout the plot of the movie. At the beginning he didn't care about his future but eventually he learned that he would regret passing up the opportunities that he was given.

Il vero protagonista di Good Will Hunting è l'insieme dei personaggi e la solida sceneggiatura, scritta da due menti giovani e brillanti che non vedevano l'ora di far sentire la propria voce attraverso una storia profonda ed incisiva. Il film nel complesso è molto coinvolgente e terreno, con un messaggio molto solido che traspare soprattutto nel finale. Quello che secondo me manca fin dal principio è il coinvolgimento visivo, caratterizzato solamente da qualche scelta registica funzionale alla narrazione e qualche geniale taglio di montaggio che lega i perfetti dialoghi dei personaggi. Nonostante questo piccolo neo il film funziona, riuscendo a trasmettere emozioni sincere dall'inizio alla fine.

With all of its accolades over the years, I was expecting more.  Good acting from Matt Damon and Robin Williams.  Minnie Driver as a lead?  I believe she was miscast, and the product of nepotism or a casting couch.  This film is dated and unbelievable.  There is never a moment that the viewer believes that Matt Damon's character is real.  The whole film is somewhat overacted.  The beginning tends to drag on and on.  "We get it, the protagonist has behavioural issues, move on already!"  We are introduced to Robin Williams character late in the film and it doesn't provide much time to build character depth.  This is a film that is not at all bad, but it isn't that good either.

Matt Damon and Robin Williams give the arguably best performance in their careers in this extremely subtle, but no less powerful character study. The director, the actors, the screenwriters- it's nothing less than emotional brilliance.
Good Will Hunting's characters, realism, heart and humour all fuse together perfectly, resulting in an outstandingly human film.

The film has good intentions and ideas where they are best depicted in amazing scenes involving Matt Damon as the titular character and Robin Williams as professor Sean McGuire (in his best dramatic role). Their chemistry is very strong and the ideas and values they talk about are both fascinating and engaging.
I wish that this whole film's plot could've just solely been about these two, but disappointingly, the screenplay written by Matt Damon and Ben Affleck is too incompetent (it's a good thing they stuck to acting I suppose). In between the thought-provoking scenes involving Damon and Williams is a cliché-ridden story told with characters that are not engaging nor have enough backstory for us, the audience, to care about. All I need to say is that it is a romance plot with the titular character and a girl and there's a misunderstood fight between them and....ugh....yeah. It's that same old 'song and dance' we all achingly know.
In fact, the effect the film had on me was a tug-of-war, pulling me back and forth between smart characters with smart dialogue and dumb characters with dumb dialogue. 
I'm teetering on the fence for "Good Will Hunting". I want to like this film, but I just can't stomach its amateur plot peppered with intelligent scenes. It (sadly) comes across as Hollywood trying to relate with the smart crowd and failing, which in turn, makes for a phony film.

Whenever we as humans see someone with something we don't have, we imagine that they must have the best life. That because they have what we don't, there life is automatically better that ours. But that is not always true. Just because a man drives a better car than you, doesn't mean that he is going home to a better life. Good Will Hunting speaks to this concept in a unique way. By showing us a glimpse of a boy who could have anything, and yet is content with a life that is less than spectacular to say the least. And it is about another man's journey to show him that he is worth more. 
	Will Hunting (Matt Damon) is a peculiar boy. He has the ability to think harder and more critically that anyone around him. But he would rather work as a janitor at Harvard, than attend. But one day while he is working, he sees a math theorem on a chalkboard and he solves it. As he is leaving, a Professor Lambau (Stellan Skarsgård) spots him and upon realizing what will has done, he proceeds to track will down, finding him in jail, due to Will's unruly attitude. The Professor convinces the Judge to put Will under his care on the condition that Will attend some math classes with him and that he see a therapist, Sean Maguire (Robin Williams) 
	This movie does a very good job at developing the relationship between its characters. They are all centered around Will, giving the movie a well-grounded feel. The movie knows what it is trying to prove and does it very well. Stellan Skarsgård's character has problem the worst relationship with Will, but that is only because he is the only one who could be seen as the antagonist. He wants Will to become the best he can be using his remarkable ability to think and learn. But in doing this, Skarsgård's character neglects Will's mental health and only thinks about what is good for his future. Robin Williams' character is different and it is his relationship with Will that carries this movie. In Williams' portrayal of physiatrist Sean Maguire, we see a man who character sees past Will incredible ability to think and can tell that he has had a hard life and that he is damaged into thinking he is less than what he is. He helps Will, first by showing him that just because he knows all the facts about everything, doesn't mean he know everything about everything. He is then able to help Will to realize that what happen to him in his childhood doesn't need to dictate his life.
	 If there is something wrong with the movie, I would say it is the conflict. The idea is that Will needs to see a therapist because Professor Lambeau bailed him out of jail. But this is quickly forgotten as soon as we meet Sean. It just gives us the idea that things would go right back to the way they were if they were allowed to with no consequences. 
	This movie does a great job of showing us that we are more than just the thoughts in our brains. We matter, to ourselves and others, and that is worth more that money and fame. But it is important to be reminded of that from time to time. We like to feel loved and this movie helps us to realize that.

With powerful performances, "Good Will Hunting" is a perfect example of excellent dialogue and compelling characters.

A young janitor grew up with a troubled childhood and little to go to, but has the brains of a genius and the work effort of a teenager. One day, when he solves a seemingly impossible math problem, he finds himself under the mentorship of a few bright minds. Although he's got the potential to be basically anything he wants, his stubbornness and fears will push not only his mentors to the test, but himself.

If anything, watch this movie for the performances. A young Matt Damon and Ben Affleck should be enough to attract most people, but watching Robin Williams in one of his best films makes you feel like you're truly in the presence of greatness. The performances are all so amazing and I actually didn't expect Matt Damon to be this good. He plays this troubled teen who has so much potential but is so damaged that he refuses to do anything about it. I love his character and he's so relatable in so many ways. Ben Affleck's role wasn't too big, but he did co-write the film, so applause to him. I had never really seen a ton of Robin William's performances and seeing him in live action felt very real and genuine. I wasn't as happy with the late introduction of his character, but he was stellar none the less. Stellan Skarsgard also had a great performance with his stand out moments, and even Minnie Driver had her moments late in the game. 

The screenplay was very well written in my opinion. It had a few stereotypes and predictable moments in there, and for the most part, it followed a fairly safe route. It did feel a little repetitive at times, as it felt like there were a lot of moments that followed the same dialogue structure and the biggest moments were fueled by purely dialogue. However, that's not always a bad thing, it just felt a little repetitive. It doesn't stray from the fact that I would replay certain scenes just for the monologues alone. 

This movie is a great character study and it was so intriguing to learn more about these characters. There are so many relatable aspects that actually brought tears to my eyes. I smiled, I was impressed, and I wanted to cry all in one film. That's always a positive. 

Now, I wasn't in love with this movie. To me, there was nothing extremely unique about this film that I haven't necessarily seen before, but this movie is the favorite film of someone very close to me. With that being said, I know I'll be able to watch this film and smile, while remembering all of the happiness and tears it brought to someone's life. This film will always be considered a classic and I'm proud to own it in my collection.

In the end, I thoroughly enjoyed this film and although I didn't love it, it'll always hold a place in my heart for different reasons.

AMAZING. It's really one of the best movies I have watched in a while. The acting was exquisite. One of the best films I've seen in a while. This film does an amazing job at making you really sympathize and care about the characters without needing endless flashbacks and drawn out monologues about their past. You figure everything out through the amazingly written dialogue that, with the help of some superb performances by the whole cast, really tell an emotional story that grips you. None of the characters are perfect, they all have their own quirks and issues that they grapple with and personality traits some would deem undesirable. But you can't help to fall in love with them, especially with the main character Will (Matt Damon) and Sean (Robin Williams). The ending is open ended and doesn't give a fairy tale happy ending while still giving you the satisfaction of guessing what happens after the film closes. It's an incredibly satisfying film that is worthy of it's praise.

I'm not saying it is offensive (although it does get mean-spirited at times), but the film is about getting out of your comfort zone and taking advantage of special talents. Some may be offended, as it doesn't tell you to choose, it forces you. The movie will make either ashamed or proud of the message, depending on who you are. Honestly, this movie had me thinking about my life and my future as a teenager for personal reasons.

When we are influenced with equations to solve life's problems, to being influenced from our friends to solve life's problems, to being influenced by professors and teachers to solve your life's problem from a deeper insight. When we needed the right guidance, the right friends, and the right love to make us enjoy life, learnibg, and doing what we enjoy or intended to do all along. When we come along way to solve life's problems without our fists, and get on the right track and road. When you watch Good Will Hunting, you have to look past the Oscars and other awards it's gotten. Because beneath all that, it's a beautiful movie, with a beautiful script written by two talented young men and acted out by equally talented actors such as Robin Williams, Matt Damon and Ben Affleck.

One of the most enjoyable parts of the movie was the psychological aspect. We have a typical 21 year old, going out and drinking with his friends, getting in fights etc., but underneath all that there's so much more to him. This movie tells us that we shouldn't look at the surface alone, there is so much more to people.

The acting in this movie was incredible, Matt Damon played the role of Will Hunting without fault, he displayed the emotions, the cockiness, he displayed how Will was closed off due to his childhood trauma and he displayed how Will shrouded his weakness with smart talk and intellect. Robin Williams played the therapist Sean Maguire, a man who has seen life unlike the life his fellow academics have, on the battlefield in Vietnam. He recently lost his wife, who he regarded as his soulmate and best friend.

Matt Damon plays Will Hunting, who is a brilliant young man who denies his out of this world genius. Will has had a very abusive childhood which hurt him mentally to a point where he can no longer let anyone close to him aside from his best friend who is played by Ben Affleck. That is until a professor at one of the top colleges finds Will's talent and helps him out of trouble with the law. Robin Williams later comes in as a therapist to Will, he is the only one who can really stand up to Will's intellect and manages to break the layer of distrust that Will has developed over years of solitude, and the two develop a bond beyond friendship. Yes there is a girl in the movie, but there isn't much focus on that aspect.

The fact that most of the people keep on talking about the probability of someone being as smart as Will tells us that this is a story, that this isn't real. Even so it relates to almost everyone who has been at Will's age. They have dealt with insecurities, fear of not being accepted, etc.

Overall, I think it's a beautiful movie, with a beautiful message and amazing effort from everyone in the cast and crew. Especially from Matt Damon and Ben Affleck, who co-wrote the script for this movie. It is definitely a must watch
The level of investment one develops for Will's (Matt Damon) and Sean's (Robin Williams) relationship is intense. Outstanding performances.

As a filmmaker and film critic, there's a few times a month that someone will ask me what my top ten favorite films are. That list fluctuates and changes over time, but there are a few constants: Martin Scorsese's "Taxi Driver," Tony Kaye's "American History X," and Gus Van Sant's "Good Will Hunting."

This film has something special about it, outside of the obvious elements of a great script and a stellar cast, which is it's striking ability to shift between pathos and uplift. That's not easy to do, but Van Sant achieves it in spades.

The meat of the film, however, comes from the beautiful subtext. This is a film with purpose. It's about individuality versus ability, self-worth versus self-sufficiency, knowledge versus wisdom, and striving to discover one's own purpose and fighting to achieve peace. "Good Will Hunting" is an important film.

I hated this movie when I first saw it. However that was a long time ago, and I was a lot more sensitive to profanity then. I guess I've, sadly, been desensitized since then so I was interested to see if I would like this movie now that the language doesn't bother me so much. It did get somewhat better. I thought the counseling scenes with Robin Williams were quite engaging and they made me care more than I expected I would. However that's about the only aspect of the movie that worked for me. I never feel like Matt Damon disappears into the role of Will, so every emotional moment just feels like obvious acting. His friends added nothing to the movie for me, and Ben Affleck is an even worse actor. Yet the real sticking point I had was that, in a strange way, I found myself sympathizing with Stellan Skarsgard. I thought the movie was more engaging when it was exploring Will's genius, instead of his emotions. That's not to say it is a bad movie, but I didn't think it was anything all that special or unique. I could watch a dozen TV movies about damaged kids trying to move past their emotional detachment, but the diamond in the rough story is one that feels more cinematic and I thought needed to take center stage. Perhaps Good Will Hunting is just not a film that works for me, because clearly others love it.

Good Will Hunting is a true masterpiece in my own eyes and has become my favorite movie of all time. Good Will Hunting doesn't need to have any gimmicks to make it special.

As far as what exactly make Good Will Hunting so special is actually not obvious at first. There isn't one thing that sticks out in this movie but is instead just overall such a solid piece. However after watching this movie year after year I can put my thumb on some of the aspects in this movie that does make it work. One positive of this movie was Matt Damon, he didn't just act as his character but became his character. This is because of Damon's understanding of his character, this is because Damon created his character. Matt Damon knew exactly what he was trying to create and was able to display it perfectly in this movie. Matt Damon is only complimented by Ben Afflecks, Robin Williams, and others roles. The development of the characters also work so well, none feel forced and it actually creates some suspense.

This movie also had a certain it factor to it. This movie has an undeniable it factor that connects to the audience like no other. This is created by the environment and attitude this movie creates. This movie sucks the audience into its own world and works so well.

In conclusion Good Will Hunting is a must watch and a true classic that will continue to change lives just like mine.

I'm late to the party on seeing this. I liked it more than I thought I would. I've seen the movie referenced and spoofed many times, so I thought my view would be a little jaded. Yet, the story it tells is still unique, sweet and fascinating. It sort of reminded me of Ordinary People, which focused on a therapist/boy relationship. It's a wonderful script. One of the smartest ones ever written. The performances are spectacular, even after so many years. Yes, I wholeheartedly agree, this is the best performance of Robin William's career. This was one of the few time when award season truly got it right. He is magnificent here. I adored his character. Hindsight really helps, however. You can unfortunately see the dark, devastated side of Robin that lurked beneath his hilarious exterior showing itself throughout this performance. This is what depression looks like. This was, in fact, the real Robin Williams, and we lost him because of it. If you thought Good Will Hunting was sad then, it's even sadder now. Still, you'd be stupid not to watch it at least once.

Good Will Hunting is an excellent drama. The performances are great, not one person in the cast is anything less than impressive. The writing is fantastic, it is very believable dialogue and perfectly fits the attitudes of these characters. The story is very predictable but is executed in a way that you don't feel like you've seen the idea hundreds of times. It is emotional too, with some very effective scenes that give backstory to make us sympathize with the characters more. It can also be surprisingly entertaining and there isn't a dull scene to be found. This is a near perfect and pretty powerful film. Good Will Hunting gets 4.5/5 stars (A).

"Some people can never believe in themselves, until someone believes in them."

Good Will Hunting is one of my favorite movies and a powerful and emotional, character driven drama. This is the type of movie I love. A movie about human struggle, human emotion, and human relationships, where the plot buildups aren't manufactured, but are real(or at least appear real). This is a masterpiece.

Will Hunting is a janitor at MIT, who lives in a rundown one bedroom apartment in South Boston. He spends his nights drinking with his friends and looking for trouble. Will has been in trouble a lot, mostly assault charges and after he gets into another fight, the judge is about to throw the book at him. In his spare time, however, Will is an avid reader and a mathematical genius. After he solves a problem on a chalkboard at MIT, that few ever have; a professor tracks him down and gets him out of jail. The terms- that he works with the professor and sees a counselor. Soon Will is excelling at his work with the professor, but is guarded about his past and scared of his future.

The performances in Good Will Hunting are extraordinary. Matt Damon gives, what I believe to be, his best performance. He exudes pain and emotion, in a powerful performance. Robin Williams is equally as haunting, as Will's psychiatrist, who tries to get Will to open up and see his potential. Minnie Driver gives a great performance as Will's love interest. As good as the performances are, the best aspect of the movie is the great script by Damon and Affleck and solid direction from Gus Van Sant. 

There are a lot of powerful moments through out Good Will Hunting, but none more than when Will finally reveals his past to the love interest, Skyler. It's a scene so real, not forced, not manufactured, but something that comes about in a natural progression of great storytelling. If you haven't seen Good Will Hunting, it is one that you should seek out.
A fantastic story with heart and relatable characters.

Good Will Hunting is not only the surprise left-field success that launched Damon and his pal/co-writer Ben Affleck into the Hollywood stratosphere, it's a smart, tenderly written tale of the ways love and friendship can help build a bridge between the memories that haunt us and the futures we dream of. The massively profitable drama earned Affleck and Damon an Oscar for Best Original Screenplay, and opened every door in Hollywood to its young stars/creators. With empathetic direction from Gus Van Sant, beautiful music from Danny Elfman and Elliott Smith, and an Oscar-winning supporting performance from Robin Williams, Good Will Hunting was the kind of film that played equally well to the arthouse and cineplex crowds, and the kind of story that makes you feel good about loving movies.

Good Will Hunting is a movie that gets so many people talking, it is loved by many and the performances too. I felt as I watched just why do so many love it, I didn't think it was perfection but there is no doubt this is an interesting piece of cinema with it's smart plot and emotionally charged characters. I did feel it was very good and although only just about, it still manages to really let you enjoy it.

The first thing to say about this is Robin Williams who is at his very best here. He just feels so excellent as his role as Sean Maguire who as you will see councils Will Hunting and he adds an extra element to this movie Robin does. All the cast are fairly strong here, Matt Damon as Will is good and really shows us what he has got for his future film career. Cast such as Ben Affleck aren't really shown as much as the two I mentioned but him among his brother Casey Affleck, Minnie Driver and Stellan Skarsgard form a good little cast for this type of film. 

Ben Affleck and Matt Damon of course write the movie and they do a great job, not only capturing everyday life situations well, but adding in Will Hunting to those scenes to make it feel smart and funny. I did however feel it was slightly contrived, mostly in the way they want to get a certain emotion out of you, sometimes you can laugh and sometimes you can be sad, even times when they want you to think "Oh wow he's smart that Will Hunting". I will also add that the script though is really showcasing the talent these two guys have, and I do feel like these guys really are an example to look up to when aspiring screenwriters come up.

Gus Van Sant directs it well and his job is made easier by the fine script brought to him. He manages to delicately direct it without making the film feel done before or too much like a typical piece of cinema. Van Sant also could be said to contribute to Williams performance and you can see Gus really worked well with the cast to make them bring the most out of the script. Another delicate thing is the score, now when you making a film about a genius from Boston, Danny Elfman doesn't always spring to mind but he manages to beautifully score it and the music is really one thing I remember the most about watching the movie.

One good thing about the movie is that it is smart, not only in movie terms but in terms of the script and the actors who all seem to remember there lines so well, it almost feels like they all know mathematics like we see in the film. I think all the credit goes to Affleck and Damon who if I'm not mistaken, are not mathematic geniuses but do the screenplay in such a way that it feels like a professor has written parts of the film.

Overall it is the ending that is the real pay off, of course I'm not going to ruin it for you but lets just say it makes you feel emotion and really draws you close to the characters we see so much of in this movie. Overall this is totally worth a watch, not only for people thinking "It's Oscar nominated, it must be good", but also people who just want an interesting film, not for those who want action or true thrills but it is definitely one for the thinkers and maybe even the unidentified genius.

This really is simply a flawless movie. I'm not saying that everyone has to like it, but for what it's trying to accomplish, Good Will Hunting makes no missteps. 

Will has a ton of character. His genius is handled very well. The fact that he's incredibly smart isn't the bulk of his character. It's moreso about how he chooses to use it, if at all, and what the people around him think he should do. A lot of different outlooks on what his intelligence is meant for come about. It's used as an engine to explore what it really means to get the most out of life. I liked seeing his evolution from start to finish, from a smart douche bag to a likable douche bag, and finally to a very complex person I sympathized with entirely.

On a technical side, it's all great. Great screenplay, nice acting, solid pacing, and a plot that wasn't at all predictable. The score was a peculiar choice: all the tracks are very light and have a sense of whimsy, which really only seemed to match up with the movie's tone towards the end. I liked it, though. I enjoyed every aspect of Good Will Hunting.

I truly love Robin Williams as an actor after watching Good Will Hunting. The movie follows the emotional story of a janitor that works at Harvard school and is extremely smart but as his past emotions come back to haunt him, he becomes confused with the direction he wants to take. Matt Damon and Robin Williams play the main characters, Will and Sean, and are perfectly cast in these roles. The two have the best chemistry out of pretty much any movie I've ever seen. It's crazy. These two have pasts that haunt them and sort of plays a factor in their understanding for each other. The stories of how they were treated when they were younger were tragic and really messed up. Good Will Hunting is the best drama of 1997.

Directed by Gus Van Sant (My Own Private Idaho (1991), To Die For (1995) and Milk (2008)), this drama started out being written by Ben Affleck and Matt Damon as a thriller set in Boston, but after getting feedback from friends and mentors, they scaled the story back considerably, to make it a more human story, one with heart and brilliant dialogue to boot. It's got some stunning performances too. Will Hunting (Damon) is a janitor who works at Massachusetts Institute of Technology, he's from South Boston and never had much of an education, but he happens to be a genius, a self-taught one too. But instead of doing something with his life, he spends much of his free time drinking with his friends Chuckie (Affleck), Billy (Cole Hauser), and Morgan (Casey Affleck). When Professor Gerald Lambeau (Stellan Skarsgård) discovers Will's gift, he decides to help him. After getting Will out of jail after a fight, the condition is Will do maths with Lambeau, and be counselled by Dr. Sean Maguire (Robin Williams), who is determined to help Will and his demons. It's a great little character piece with some colourful characters, and it's also a love letter to Damon and Affleck's native Boston too. They rightfully won the Best Original Screenplay Oscar for their script, while the story might be predictable, it's the characters that drive the story along, and it's very sharp and observant.

A wonderful story starring the late Robin Williams about an incredibly gifted boy with his fair share of issues along the way. Williams plays the part of a therapist who has been given the task of "fixing" Damon's character. A wonderful film.

This movie is one of my favorite movies, and is easily my favorite Robin Williams movie. Coming from a background of stand up comedy and mostly comedic films, one wouldn't think he would do well in a serious role, but he perfected his role in this movie. He provided some comedic relief, but his real genius was in the many scenes working with the young and troubled Matt Damon. Many of the supporting roles were also very well done, especially the performances of Ben Affleck and Minnie Driver. Matt Damon played the part he wrote for himself extremely well, and I'm not sure which was better, his script writing or his ability to make the troubled genius that is Will Hunting come alive. Every time I watch this movie I am left speechless, and I highly suggest it, and think it is one of the best two hours you will ever spend.

Although now Matt Damon is a bona fide superstar with an action trilogy and a heist trilogy both securely under his belt, there was a time when he wasn't so well known as to have his own marionette in Team America. With a few bit parts and a couple of supporting roles behind him, Damon had yet to make any sort of lasting mark on cinema. Ben Affleck, similarly, hadn't yet moved into the legitimate public eye, despite roles in Chasing Amy and Dazed and Confused. Then there was Good Will Hunting. 

The story follows a South Boston construction worker with an unusual gift for mathematics. After he's discovered by an MIT professor and put under his supervision as a result of an assault charge, he's suddenly faced with a lot of important decisions. 

Gus Van Sant's direction here is flawlessly old school. Long, lingering shots with minimalist camera work and just the right amount of emotion makes for some beautifully restrained work. Think David Fincher's work with the Social Network but with less cutting. The nature of the film demands a careful balance of humour and emotion and Van Sant never drops the ball. When it's supposed to be funny, you'll be laughing. When you're meant to be sad, there will be tears. Despite his often childlike apporach to the material, he is able to be unflinchingly mature in the moments that call for it. It's this versatility which is the mark of a great director that Van Sant displays so intuitively here. 

Good Will Hunting also features one of Danny Elfman's more diverse compositions, a bittersweet combination of keys and strings with a lilting pipe tune which stays with you for a while. It may verge on twee on the odd occassion but it's used with enough restraint that it doesn't become a crutch or substitute for real emotion. The real standout of the soundtrack is Elliott Smith's Oscar nominated song "Miss Misery." Hitting just the right note, his full stop at the end of the film is sweetly depressing as well as marking a new chapter for our main character. 

Speaking of the Academy Awards, one of the biggest draws of the film is the Oscar winning script penned by Matt Damon and Ben Affleck. Thirteen years on and it's still as powerful as it ever was, managing to walk the line between stilted and realistic with an uncanny instinct for everyday conversations and natural dialogue. Even Will's super smart outbursts are grounded by the film's realistic feel. But the screenplay's greatest achievement is the raw emotion that it is capable of evoking. Scenes such as Skylah and Will's fight in the dorm room linger in the mind long after the final credits have rolled. In particular the dialogue between Will and Sean is incredibly powerful, their exchanges both layered and meaningful. Their relationship development is incredibly rewarding, moving from the sizing up of two boys from Southie to two friends with grace and realism. The elegance and simplicity of the plot is astoundingly straightforward with no sudden, attention seeking twists or unstable divergences, instead focussing on extracting every moment of nuance and emotion from various conversations between the characters. It's an incredible achievement, especially in light of the fact that it's the writing debut of Damon and Affleck. 

The two of them don't let down in the acting department either, with both of them turning in brilliant performances. Damon's character is the main character of the piece and as such his performance is more rewarding in depth and evolution but Affleck does well with the screentime allotted to him. He is funny and loudmouthed as well as playing the role of Will's best friend with uncharacteristic restraint. Damon's performance easily outshines him, however, moving from dangerously inflamed to easy-going with style. Jason Bourne may be his best known character but his performance here is so beautifully vulnerable and simply realistic that it's easily his best performance to date. His love interest in the film is a delightful Minnie Driver who is able to evoke a goofy sense of humour at times while being undeniably powerful in the more emotional scenes. But the star here is Robin Williams, the manic stand-up bringing forth an incredible performance filled with nuance and humour as well as depth and vulnerability. His delivery of some exquisitely crafted speeches make an incredible document almost obsolete with such astounding timing and realism that it's difficult to tell where the acting ends and Williams begins. He is quietly, understatedly brilliant in the midst of an incredible cast. 

With an eternally brilliant script, beautiful direction and amazing performances all round, Good Will Hunting is as close to perfect as movies get.
