'Good Will Hunting' is directed by Gus Van Sant and stars Matt Damon, Robin Williams, Ben Affleck,  Stellan Skarsgard, Minnie Driver and Casey Affleck.

'Good Will Hunting' is about a young, genius boy named Will(Matt Damon) from South Boston. He works as a janitor and he has a photographic memory. His gift allows him to excel in the field of mathematics but chooses to live a life drinking with his friends and not fulfilling his life's potential.
With his life slowly crashing and burning he gets help from a university professor and a psychiatrist to rebuild his life and solve the problems from his past and focus on his future.

This is a warm hearted movie, it may not seem like it initially as we're introduced to an intimidating Will Hunting but the movie sets it up and executes his motives quite effectively. 
The group of friends he hangs out with is a lot of fun. Their constant jokes and mocking of each other cracks me up and makes me wish I have friends as awesome as they are. We are welcomed to their group and it is established who is the smart one, the dumb one, the best mate, you get it and it just wants me be involved so much.
Seeing Robin Williams here is interesting. Just like in my recent review of 'Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind' and seeing Jim Carrey play in a drama proved to be achieved in a believable and compelling way. The same goes for Williams. Both actors were famous for their outrageous comedic personalities and performances and now having them appear in dramas shakes my head in amazement. 
Back to William's character, he was solid, charismatic and likeable. He reminds me of the cuddly uncle I never had. The one who would give advice about life and share stories to his grandchildren, William's portrayed him very well.

What sets the bar quite high here is the script and connection we have between all the characters. The dialogue is written so well with some perfect one liners, jokes and memorable quotes. Conversations aren't at all convenient and by that I mean written in a corny way or sappy fashion. Break up, conflict and social scenes are so natural and doesn't make it feel fake at any point.

'Good Will Hunting' is a spectacular movie. It definitely fed me inspiration in a way a regular personal development speaker would not be able to. No surprise it won some Oscars. 
Chances are after you see this it'll be part of your long term movie collection.
This film is hands down my favorite film for life; seen it a hundred times and it never gets old..

I just re-watched this movie after many, many years, and realized that I've never reviewed it here on Flixster. So...

 It really is one of the best films of our lifetime (thus far), and is a true testament to the talent of Matt Damon and Ben Affleck (who both were only in their early twenties when they made this!).

For much of the film, the vibe is gritty and troubled, and it puts a lump in your throat. But the overall message and narrative of the film is one of hope, introspection, and the simplicity of what defines happiness. It's a must see for anyone who hasn't already seen it. It's a true classic.

ADDENDUM: It would be remiss of me to not also mention Robin Williams's performance in this film. Too often he is typecast as a one-trick pony (admittedly, oftentimes, by myself). This film serves as proof-positive that he's a true artist, and is a very gifted actor. Couple this with other films of his, like that of "The Night Listener" (I don't care what anyone says -- I liked that movie), and his talent for the art of acting becomes undeniable.

" I'd ask you about love, you'd probably quote me a sonnet. But you've never looked at a woman and been totally vulnerable. Known someone that could level you with her eyes, feeling like God put an angel on earth just for you. Who could rescue you from the depths of hell. And you wouldn't know what it's like to be her angel, to have that love for her, be there forever, through anything.

Just about the perfect feel-good film, it's a shame the pairing of Matt Damon and Ben Affleck haven't been able to create another masterpiece together in the fifteen years since. 

Perfection with every word, each one thought out to create a prolonged effect and feeling on the viewer days after its credits roll, the script is the films ace. There are several life-changing moments for the characters, and several revelations about what certain characters mean to each other that you don't expect; every single one of them you go through the transition with. It's almost trying to teach you everything there is that's important in life, and regardless of whether you knew it before it will make you feel like it's fresh.

A powerhouse of performances is the films second ingredient of brilliance. Robin Williams, in a role he developed and re-worked himself puts in the performance of his career. Therapist Sean McGuire is the man tasked with helping delve into the psyche of Matt Damon's Will Hunting, and Williams does it with the lightest and subtlest touches. It's a masterpiece of a role, and seeing how some of McGuire's best moments were ad-libbed, it's tribute to exactly how much Williams understood this character that makes the Oscar he received more than deserved.

Matt Damon is also exceptional, finding the shades of grey needed for Will Hunting, then allowing them to be broken down piece by piece as more and more of his life is uncovered. The pair are not alone though as the supporting cast are equally strong. Affleck shines through as Hunting's friend Chuckie, particularly in a surprisingly touching number of scenes in the films final act. Minnie Driver wins over you heart as Skylar, and even though her character isn't given the screen time you want to wrap up her character arc it somehow isn't needed. 

Through and throughout, Good Will Hunting will put a smile on your face, and you'll never be more happy to watch the entire credits in the hope that there is just a tiny bit more insight into the world of these perfectly crafted characters. 

As close to cinema perfection as there is.

This story is about a young and rebellious janitor Will Hunting (Matt Damon) from South Boston working at MIT school in Cambridge, but unbeknownst to anyone except his friends Will is a self educated genius. Smarter even than MIT's shining star professor and Fields Medal winner Dr. Gerald Lambeau (Stellan Skarsgård), Will catches the attention of Dr. Lambeau when he secretly solves a math formula at work one night that only a handful of people could solve. Eager to work with this young genius after tracking him down, Dr. Lambeau finds out he is a rebellious young man who's facing jail time after a street fight escalates into Will hitting a police officer. So young will is given a free pass on the condition he work with the Professor and see a therapist, but the only therapist that has a chance of getting close to the hard edged and guarded genius is Dr. Lambeau's old college roommate Sean McGuire (Robin Williams).
This is a solid plot with great acting and very good character development about this young genius who has to face some painful memories from his dark past if he wants any chance of breaking free from his suffocating and dead end lifestyle. Opening old wounds, he begins to take chances in life and work through his trust issues.
It's not your fault if you like this movie, it's not your fault. It's not your fault.

The name of the film is as smart and powerful as the movie itself. Good Will Hunting is about a janitor (Damon) who doesn't use his outstanding intelligence the way he should, consequently he fails to live his life to his full potential. A therapist (Williams)is hired to boost his confidence and open his eyes. And it's pretty predictable when it unfolds, but this movie is proof that emotional performances and heart can be just as entertaining as a film with a well constructed plot. Sommetimes it got scary and/or funny. It's a drama that deserves to remain a classic because it's a deeply inspiring movie and I loved watching it.

Matt Damon has played many great roles, but it's hard to think of a better one than the troubled yet brilliant math prodigy he portrays in Good Will Hunting. The story, dialogue, and acting in this film feels fresh no matter how many times I watch this picture. I recommend it highly.

Harvard doesn't so much seem to be a university as it does a fictional land of ethereal genius.  I imagine its student body sexy like the misanthropes of "Cruel Intentions," uniformed like the young wizards of Hogwarts, adept in the art of conversation like any character in a given Aaron Sorkin penned TV series.  A friend of mine goes there, being the basketball playing Emmy Noether of our middle-of-the-road home town, and confounding is the way those around her unanimously display uncharted characteristics of brilliance.  Missing are the students unsure of where their future might take them - with most loaded with cash and otherworldly brain function, the world is an oyster encrusted with a monolith of a pearl.  They could be a doctor or a chemist or a lawyer or an engineer, no what-ifs implemented within the scenery.  Part of me would love to meet them with an eye-roll and an edged-out scoff, but another, too undoubtedly impressed, would be too in awe to put forth such disdain.  How nice it would be to be boundless in everything you do.
	But imagine if the person embodying such versatility had no drive, and had no plans to utilize their cerebral capability, preferring custodial work to achieving a degree.  You wouldn't want to stand alongside them and let them throw away their unfathomable aptitude - you'd want to knock some sense into them, turning their apathy into ambition and getting them out of their standstill of a current life.  	
	One such unmotivated figurehead is "Good Will Hunting's" titular protagonist (portrayed by Matt Damon), a twenty-year-old slacker who holds great intellectual ability (he has eidetic memory) but isn't much inclined to harness it.  As a perpetual idler who spends his days drinking with his immature set of buddies, he works as a janitor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology rather than an attendee, to the annoyance of us and his friends that know he's worthy of something greater.  But Will won't have it - he has no goals in sight, and figures he'd be perfectly happy doing handiwork until retirement becomes him.  Bully for him when he daftly solves a challenge problem posted by one of the math professors; his competency doesn't go unnoticed, and from there does his journey into self-actualization begin.
	It's all a matter of coincidence, really.  As the institute attempts to figure out who finished the problem, Will flees the scene, worried that he will no longer be able to survive on his minimum-wage life because adult figures might force him to do something more meaningful with his life.  So when he later assaults a childhood foe and the police officer who tries to make peace, he faces arrest, but is able to skirt past it when Professor Gerald Lambeau (Stellan Skarsgård), the man who posted the math problem, proposes that he privately study the field with him while also attending regular therapy instead.  As learning and divulging one's problems is more appetizing than spending a couple months in a jail cell, Will agrees, much to his disliking.
	But, of course, such activities prompt him to realize that he can't keep going on the path that he has been for the rest of his existence.  He likes to drunkenly mess around with his friends, but he might like Skylar (Minnie Driver), a British Harvard student he begins romancing, better.  He likes to tell himself that hammering drywall is a more valid job than solving mathematical proofs, but he might think otherwise the more he sees Sean McGuire (Robin Williams), the psychologist he's expected to talk with that eventually becomes a sort of confidant.  The film's events just might be the most emotional and confusing of Will Hunting's life - but he'd better get the girl and better stop slacking off in the end.  He needs to.
	I have a theory, anyway, that a movie should be able to be predictable so long as we want a happy ending, and if we want its characters to prosper.  If emotional manipulation isn't a part of the equation, why not give us what we desire? "Good Will Hunting," a smart crowdpleaser that undercuts its realism by warming the heart, earns its good-natured conclusion - it's the sort of film we could watch over and over again, its dialogue and acting so voracious and interesting that its feel-good twist is the very thing that keeps us coming back for more all these years later.
	Part of its charm, too, is its working as a breakthrough for so many of those involved.  It brought avant garde filmmaker Gus Van Sant his first worldwide success, and it propelled Damon and Ben Affleck to superstardom, winning them both Oscars for their screenplay as well as defining them as acting talents of weighty ability.  It brought Williams, poignant as Will's therapist, a trophy for his supporting turn, and got Driver, the most engrossing love interest of the decade, a nomination.  Because "Good Will Hunting" is a work that doesn't just make an impression; it also gallantly affects us, going beyond mere satisfying filmmaking because it touches us in ways few films can manage.  You might as well treat yourself to a viewing following the reading of this final sentence; it makes for a wonderful way to spend a couple of hours, and a little cinematic dopamine here and there can be a terrific thing.

Good Will Hunting is manipulative and spends a good half the film playing your emotions like a piano, but it is so effective that even while you know full well what it is trying to do you can't help but allow yourself to get involved.

Will Hunting is a young tearaway floating aimlessly through life as his youth evaporates, yet unwilling to start making the grown up decisions. He spends most days with his three buddies hanging out, swearing, trashtalking, fighting and drinking, and his own personal time is spent janitoring and reading...

His friends are more the "whadda you lookin' at?" type, and it is during the fighting part of his day that Will inadvertently takes a swing at a local cop.

Will does his janitorin' at a local college in Boston where a professor named Lambeaux (Stellen Skarsgaard) has posed a mathematical equation as a special challenge to his large group of students, he proposed that anyone who could solve this unbelievably complex problem would get a special prize and acknowledgment.

Will came across the equation on a whiteboard when cleaning after hours and...

Shortly after Lambeaux realises the complex equation has been solved - and with no-one coming forward to claim credit for the feat - Lambeaux sets another, more complicated puzzle. He proclaims that while he doubts anyone will solve this one should they do so it will prove the first was no fluke.

Will has a quick squiz and promptly puts the answer up on the board to something that took teams of mathematicians months to solve working in unison.

But Will doesn't want any attention or acclaim, when confronted about his acts he runs off to a night on the town with his friends once more. Will's buddies are simple hard working guys who also play hard, they tease each other unmercifully and seem resigned that this is how their lives will pan out forever. Meanwhile will gives a verbal beatdown to a pretentious egghead in the pub and simultaneously manages to pick up Skyla (Minnie Driver).

Unfortunately thanks to punching the policeman Will is also thrown in prison to await sentencing for his assault. After Lambeaux manages to track him down he witnesses Will defending himself, citing obscure cases and verdicts as precedents and running verbal rings around the more experienced prosecutor.

Yep. Still smart.

But the judge ain't havin' it this time... and Will is sentenced to a stretch in the pen.

To fast forward a little Lambeaux manages to pull some strings and has Will released from prison on two conditions, the first that he spend some time with the maths team to see just how deep Will's intelligence and abilities go, the second that Will seek professional psychiatric help for his personal issues and anger management.

Will agrees, but probably more because he wants to get a shot at Skyla.

Will enjoys the maths side of the equation (get it?), but is far more reluctant to let someone into his head, he cuts a swathe through various shrinks, sidestepping real questions and disarming them with his superior intellect.

Enter Shaun (Robin Williams) a long time friend of Lambeaux and basically the last chance at success. The initial meetings and chats are perfunctory exercises, at best silent at worst rocky and heated, but both Shaun and Will gradually realise that there is more to the other than meets the eye. Shaun feels that Will is incredibly gifted but a little naïve and unsure of how to use his talents, but Will thinks that Shaun too is "slumming it" a little and taking the easy way out.

As the tenuous relationship grows more trusting and each comes to rely more on the other decisions must be made.

Lambeaux feels that Will is a once in a generation mind that could rival Einstein, he wants to "discover" him and unveil him to the world, Shaun only wants Will to think for himself and not merely recite what he knows from reading books and hearing others. More than anything though Will's buddies all know that he could be so much more than a janitor or construction worker, and while they bust their guts trying to get by they desperately want Will to use his natural talents to do something for himself.

And all the while Skyla and her big head remain in Will's thoughts...

Good Will Hunting has some excellent dialogue - so much so that it baffles me to think that Matt Damon and Ben Affleck came up with all this in their teens, even though Affleck has backed it up as a director - it is well paced, intelligent and always interesting. Near the end of the film the plot threatens briefly to get a little bit ahead of itself but the loose ends are all neatly pulled together for the conclusion, which while not being incredibly satisfying served to wrap things up nicely.

Robin Williams is thankfully low key and realistic as Shaun, Matt Damon proved that he could act even then, and Skarsgaard has the unenviable role of being the bad guy, but he manages to show full justification for his desires.

Good Will Hunting has become a bit of a punchline through the years, the "How do you like them apples" bit has been parodied, as has the success of the film in Jay and Silent Bob Strike Back (in a hilarious way too), but you can't ignore the impact that the film has when you watch it.

Final Rating - 8.5 / 10. I remembered it more as a relic of the 90s, an anomaly that was inexplicably successful, rewatching it the other night showed me that it was worthy of the acclaim and the box office, like Will himself this is pretty exceptional.

Now, even though it is an Oscar winner, I really wasn't expecting much. But wow was I surprised. The story is heartfelt and real. The acting is fantastic. Matt Damon does an excellent job of playing a character with a million layers to his true personality and past, and as these layers are slowly stripped away throughout the movie, he becomes a freer person. Personally, I think this is Robin Williams best role. His monologue about Will knowing everything from books but his character actually experiencing life was honest and genuine, and even though it's delivered almost deadpan, you can just feel the emotion behind the words. Damon and Affleck did a good job of weaving the romance subplot into Will's overall story, without letting it distract from the overall story. In fact, it enhanced it. Story of love? Story of Redemption? Who knows. But, it's a great movie that if you haven't seen yet, watch it before the Oscars tonight :)

The scene where Robin Williams' Sean Maguire sits on a park bench with Matt Damon's Will Hunting to have their little shrink session about life, love, and identity is perhaps my favorite cinematic moment ever. More than a conversation, it is a monologue that Robin Williams delivers with incredible passion and it gives me goosebumps every time I watch this scene. It's the reason why he won an Academy Award for best supporting actor and why the film works as well as it does. This is just one fantastic moment, but I can think of many more scenes that left me completely in love with the movie. Like the scene where Sean Maguire and Stellan Skarsgard's Prof. Lambeau have their long awaited discussion about ego and missed opportunities ("You think I'm a failure. I know who I am, and I'm proud of what I do. I was a conscientious choice, I didn't ef up! And you and your cronies think I'm some sort of pity case. You and your kiss-ass chorus following you around going, "The Fields Medal! The Fields Medal!" Why are you still so efin' afraid of failure?"), the scene where Sean narrates Game 6 of the World Series to Will, which he passed on for the opportunity to meet his future wife (I just slid my ticket across the table, and I said, "Sorry, guys; I gotta see about a girl."), and of course the final scene between Will And Sean which I don't want to spoil. There are just so many great moments in this film thanks to the strong performances and the amazing screenplay from Matt Damon and Ben Affleck which is one of my favorites. Even the scenes between Matt Damon and Ben Affleck and between Damon and Minnie Driver are incredible and I still have to leave them out of my top five favorite scenes in this movie because there are just so many. And I even left out Will's amazing monologue about why he shouldn't work for the N.S.A. It's simply one of the best written movies ever and it has Robin Williams best performance (that is saying a lot considering how much I loved his work in Dead Poet's Society, Good Morning Vietnam, and The Fisher King).            

"You're not perfect, sport, and let me save you the suspense: this girl you've met, she's not perfect either. But the question is whether or not you're perfect for each other." 

I don't know if Good Will Hunting is a perfect film, but I know it is perfect for me and for that reason it will always be included as one of my all time favorite films up there with The Sixth Sense and The Dark Knight. I have plenty of other favorites which I sometimes include in my top ten, but those three are always at the very top of my list, and I don't even worry about having to discuss it with anyone else.

Good Will Hunting has quite an inspirational story behind it's creation. Young first time out screenwriters Matt Damon and Ben Affleck knocked their first attempt out of the water with this moving tale about a young brilliant mind who lives life by avoiding it. When his therapist befriends and challenges his views on life Will Hunting is forever changed. The best thing about this film is that it rides on it's brilliant performances, as good as the script is without the cast this film put together it would not have worked. We are graced with moving scene after moving scene, one in particular towards the end where Ben Affleck informs his friend that his is envious of the gift he has and feels he's an idiot for wasting it. This film will stand the test of time for it's heart.

"I'd ask you about love, you'd probably quote me a sonnet. But you've never looked at a woman and been totally vulnerable. Known someone that could level you with her eyes, feeling like God put an angel on earth just for you."

The scene where Robin Williams' Sean Maguire sits on a park bench with Matt Damon's Will Hunting to have their little shrink session about life, love, and identity is perhaps my favorite cinematic moment ever. More than a conversation, it is a monologue that Robin Williams delivers with incredible passion and it gives me goosebumps every time I watch this scene. It's the reason why he won an Academy Award for best supporting actor and why the film works as well as it does. This is just one fantastic moment, but I can think of many more scenes that left me completely in love with the movie. Like the scene where Sean Maguire and Stellan Skarsgard's Prof. Lambeau have their long awaited discussion about ego and missed opportunities ("You think I'm a failure. I know who I am, and I'm proud of what I do. I was a conscientious choice, I didn't ef up! And you and your cronies think I'm some sort of pity case. You and your kiss-ass chorus following you around going, "The Fields Medal! The Fields Medal!" Why are you still so efin' afraid of failure?"), the scene where Sean narrates Game 6 of the World Series to Will, which he passed on for the opportunity to meet his future wife (I just slid my ticket across the table, and I said, "Sorry, guys; I gotta see about a girl."), and of course the final scene between Will And Sean which I don't want to spoil. There are just so many great moments in this film thanks to the strong performances and the amazing screenplay from Matt Damon and Ben Affleck which is one of my favorites. Even the scenes between Matt Damon and Ben Affleck and between Damon and Minnie Driver are incredible and I still have to leave them out of my top five favorite scenes in this movie because there are just so many. And I even left out Will's amazing monologue about why he shouldn't work for the N.S.A. It's simply one of the best written movies ever and it has Robin Williams best performance (that is saying a lot considering how much I loved his work in Dead Poet's Society, Good Morning Vietnam, and The Fisher King).            

"You're not perfect, sport, and let me save you the suspense: this girl you've met, she's not perfect either. But the question is whether or not you're perfect for each other." 

I don't know if Good Will Hunting is a perfect film, but I know it is perfect for me and for that reason it will always be included as one of my all time favorite films up there with The Sixth Sense and The Dark Knight. I have plenty of other favorites which I sometimes include in my top ten, but those three are always at the very top of my list, and I don't even worry about having to discuss it with anyone else.

Although now Matt Damon is a bona fide superstar with an action trilogy and a heist trilogy both securely under his belt, there was a time when he wasn't so well known as to have his own marionette in Team America. With a few bit parts and a couple of supporting roles behind him, Damon had yet to make any sort of lasting mark on cinema. Ben Affleck, similarly, hadn't yet moved into the legitimate public eye, despite roles in Chasing Amy and Dazed and Confused. Then there was Good Will Hunting.

The story follows a South Boston construction worker with an unusual gift for mathematics. After he's discovered by an MIT professor and put under his supervision as a result of an assault charge, he's suddenly faced with a lot of important decisions.

Gus Van Sant's direction here is flawlessly old school. Long, lingering shots with minimalist camera work and just the right amount of emotion makes for some beautifully restrained work. Think David Fincher's work with the Social Network but with less cutting. The nature of the film demands a careful balance of humour and emotion and Van Sant never drops the ball. When it's supposed to be funny, you'll be laughing. When you're meant to be sad, there will be tears. Despite his often childlike apporach to the material, he is able to be unflinchingly mature in the moments that call for it. It's this versatility which is the mark of a great director that Van Sant displays so intuitively here.

Good Will Hunting also features one of Danny Elfman's more diverse compositions, a bittersweet combination of keys and strings with a lilting pipe tune which stays with you for a while. It may verge on twee on the odd occassion but it's used with enough restraint that it doesn't become a crutch or substitute for real emotion. The real standout of the soundtrack is Elliott Smith's Oscar nominated song "Miss Misery." Hitting just the right note, his full stop at the end of the film is sweetly depressing as well as marking a new chapter for our main character.

Speaking of the Academy Awards, one of the biggest draws of the film is the Oscar winning script penned by Matt Damon and Ben Affleck. Thirteen years on and it's still as powerful as it ever was, managing to walk the line between stilted and realistic with an uncanny instinct for everyday conversations and natural dialogue. Even Will's super smart outbursts are grounded by the film's realistic feel. But the screenplay's greatest achievement is the raw emotion that it is capable of evoking. Scenes such as Skylah and Will's fight in the dorm room linger in the mind long after the final credits have rolled. In particular the dialogue between Will and Sean is incredibly powerful, their exchanges both layered and meaningful. Their relationship development is incredibly rewarding, moving from the sizing up of two boys from Southie to two friends with grace and realism. The elegance and simplicity of the plot is astoundingly straightforward with no sudden, attention seeking twists or unstable divergences, instead focussing on extracting every moment of nuance and emotion from various conversations between the characters. It's an incredible achievement, especially in light of the fact that it's the writing debut of Damon and Affleck.

The two of them don't let down in the acting department either, with both of them turning in brilliant performances. Damon's character is the main character of the piece and as such his performance is more rewarding in depth and evolution but Affleck does well with the screentime allotted to him. He is funny and loudmouthed as well as playing the role of Will's best friend with uncharacteristic restraint. Damon's performance easily outshines him, however, moving from dangerously inflamed to easy-going with style. Jason Bourne may be his best known character but his performance here is so beautifully vulnerable and simply realistic that it's easily his best performance to date. His love interest in the film is a delightful Minnie Driver who is able to evoke a goofy sense of humour at times while being undeniably powerful in the more emotional scenes. But the star here is Robin Williams, the manic stand-up bringing forth an incredible performance filled with nuance and humour as well as depth and vulnerability. His delivery of some exquisitely crafted speeches make an incredible document almost obsolete with such astounding timing and realism that it's difficult to tell where the acting ends and Williams begins. He is quietly, understatedly brilliant in the midst of an incredible cast.

With an eternally brilliant script, beautiful direction and amazing performances all round, Good Will Hunting is as close to perfect as movies get.

Defining Scene:
Tough one to pick but it has to be Sean and Will's second meeting. A rivetting piece of acting from Williams combined with one of the best monologues in the film.

Good Will Hunting is a film, which within the first 30 minutes of watching you know is going to be bonifide classic. Itâ(TM)s one of those film that whilst watching it, you think to yourself with a melancholy grin âIâ(TM)ll never right anything as good as thisâ, which is all the more surprising considering that it was written by Matt Damon and Ben Affleck whom both star in the movie.

Everything about this movie oozes that heart-warming, classic quality. From the performances most notably the lead Matt Damon whom plays Will Hunting a damaged individual with great intelligence and Robin Williams who plays his psychiatrist Sean, To the morale story and ending that proceeds, to every snappy and inspring dialogue exchange, this movie is beautiful.

Essentially, the movie is about the friendship of two lonely individuals whom are scared to âplay a hand in lifeâ, not Willâ(TM)s superior intellect, nor the manipulation of society. Both Sean and Will need each other, in order to move on in life, even if the two try and deny/avoid it throughout. Instead of the movie becoming a full-on soppy drama, there are injections of humor and violence, which prevent the audience from being too complacent, and Gus Van Sant deserves props for this.

Good Will Hunting, although predictable is filled to the brim with everything that one could imagine to see in a movie going-experience, though all is done with such superb quality, to the extent that the lessons learnt will last for life.

A paramount of film making at its best, this Gus Van Sant film truly inspires the mind while telling a story. Movie making is an art and only those movies which can keep an audience enthralled for its entire length can be called great. In this we can say that it is definitely very opinionated as what enthralls a certain person might not do the same for another. But sometimes a rare gem is produced which captivates all audiences and all sections of people regardless of their own likes and dislikes. Good Will Hunting is certainly one of those movies. The premise of this film is a relatively simple one but it takes a great deal of introspection to even delve into what actually makes this movie brilliant. This film plays host to a very good cast which includes the likes of Matt Damon in his breakthrough role as the protagonist Will Hunting, Robin Williams as the troubled shrink Sean Maguire, Ben Affleck as ?Chuckie?, Minnie Driver as Skylar and Stellan Skarsgard as Professor Gerald Lambeau. 
The screenplay itself is a work of art which makes the film instantly quotable, like Casablanca. The plot revolves around south Boston which is the relatively poor section of Boston, where four friends drink and make merry with all sorts of debauchery and the like. The movie really begins when Will gets arrested for assault and is presented a reprieve by the court. Will is portrayed as a troubled youth who is incredibly intelligent and can solve mathematical problems that baffle the rest of the academia. Lambeau discovers this when he sets his students a very difficult problem and finds out that it was solved by one of the janitors whom he later identifies as Will and immediately tries to get Will to alter his current lifestyle in order to get him to focus on his own life and achieve the greatness that he undoubtedly can. He tries to get him to see psychiatrists as per the court order but is unable to find one who can handle Will?s personality and finally calls on his old college roommate Sean Maguire.
 What really strikes gold in this movie is the subtle relationships of the persons involved. As Sean tells Lambeau, the reason Will hangs around with his ?retarded gorilla? friends is because they would lay down their lives and take a bat to his head at the drop of a hat. The concept of Freudian psycho social development is very interestingly portrayed with the sessions between Will and Sean. These sessions in my opinion forms the crux of the movie and shows us the depth in both the characters. A scene especially comes to mind where Sean takes Will down to the lake and tells him that he is in fact a kid, a very smart kid but just a kid. Will?s personality throughout the movie is one of detachment and sarcasm. This is what is completely focused on during the sessions with Sean. To over analyze this film would be to take away the simplicity of the movie and that would really damper the style in which this movie has been made. Will?s relationship with Skylar is a very, for lack of a better term, complicated yet sweet affair. The way her character is portrayed is fascinating. She is shown as a woman who is very well to do with no air about it. She in fact says that she would give all her money away for just another day with her father. Driver plays her part extremely well being the girl that changes Will?s life. The movie progresses at a very steady pace and you can identify with a lot of the nuances in the movie. Written by Matt Damon and Ben Affleck themselves, earning an academy award for best original screenplay and another academy award for Robin Williams for best actor in a supporting role. One of the most touching scenes in the film is where Sean and Will both share that they were victims of child abuse and Sean helps Will understand that it was not his fault in anyway and thus pushing him onto the road for recovery. 
The movie at its base is probably about the complex relationship between a rough, troubled, extraordinarily gifted working class youngster and his equally messed up therapist. Matt Damon plays his part to perfection making the step by step transformation very credible and extremely believable. The soundtrack perfectly complements the dialogue and direction and gives it that something extra.
All in all a brilliant performance by Damon in the lead, a superlative performance by Williams and the rest of the cast makes this psychological drama one for the ages. In the end, this movie is beautifully made, engaging till the very end and often very touching.

"Good Will Hunting" is the story of Will Hunting played by Matt Damon. He is a young man who is a mathematical genius but has no formal education and who is so traumatized by his past that he will not allow himself to be the man he could be with the talents he possesses. Will works as a Janitor, but chose the Massachusetts institute of technology (the finest mathematical institution in America as we are told) as the place to work in order to be close to an outlet for his brilliance. Early on in the story, the resident Math guru Professor Gerry Lambeau (played by Stellan Skarsgard) sets a problem for his students to solve which should take the whole semester for the average mind. When this problem is solved and written on the faculty blackboard the very next morning, he sets another that took him personally two years to solve. The following day he is conversing with a colleague when he witnesses Will writing down the perfect solution on the blackboard again. The Professor realizes he has a genius hiding in his midst.

When Will is later involved in a fight, he is eventually given the choice between a short prison term or working with the Professor on a daily basis and also attending psychiatric therapy sessions. Will chooses the latter but uses the therapy sessions as a chance to mock the Psychiatrists assigned to him and show off his knowledge. When no one else will work with him, Professor Lambeau turns to his old room mate at college, Sean MacGuire (played by Robin Williams on Oscar winning form.) who manages to reach the boy emotionally and start to repair the damage that has been done to him.

It is widely known that Matt Damon and Ben Affleck co wrote the screen play as a reaction to their slow progress in establishing Hollywood careers. It is a testament to their talent as writers that they came up with so many touching scenes and dialogue. In particular, Williams monologue to Damon as they sat on the park bench is touching and profound. Will's relationship with "Skylar" (played by Minnie Driver) is perfectly believable and as the story unfolds the viewer can see the change in Will's character from the cocky kid, pushing everyone away, to the young man who understands who he could be with the right encouragement.

There are very few flaws to be found in this film, largely because the story is so well told and Robin Williams performance is worth the entry price alone. It is a genuinely touching experience which relates to so many people and is easy to empathize with in real life. The characters are richly written. You really do care what happens to these people...Which is the mark of any good movie, in my opinion.

Not to mention the casting was near perfect. Robin Williams shines in his role and deserved his Oscar win. Sometimes it's easy to question when they give The supporting actor award to someone who cut his teeth in comedy like Robin Williams, it's looked more as a token award at times, but Williams performance is anything but. Just a truly amazing performance. Good performance from Matt Damon in the central role, I mean he does get a bit annoying at times but that's the mark of a great character performance, because i feel he was intended to annoy you in way. Stellan Skarsgard who is quite simply one of the greatest character actors to step foot outside of Europe, as always "shines". Ben Affleck doesn't do anything he's not known for already, but still was good as the "big brother type", Minnie Driver and Matt Damon's on-screen chemistry was undeniable, and for the most part enjoyed Driver's performance at times but also found her a little too "goofy" for my tastes. Casey Affleck and Cole Hauser also give some decent lines but nothing too memorable.

Overall, I thought this movie was believable and touching, without your typical ending. Matt Damon and Ben Affleck really have done themselves good, with the magnificent writing of the film and deserved the praise and the Oscars for their work. But My advice: Forget the Oscar nominations, the rave reviews, the famous faces, and sit down to watch this movie with a completely impartial attitude. You will see that it really is great film. All in all an uplifting and worthwhile film, which will stay with you long after.

Every time I watch "Good Will Hunting" I am taken aback. I always forget how simple, elegant and honest this film is. How exquisitely acted and directed it is. Gus Van Sant knew exactly how to handle Matt Damon and Ben Affleck's screenplay. By letting the story speak for itself and foregoing the intrusion of directorial flourishes, Van Sant makes a powerful story speak even louder. This is a story than can speak to anyone and Van Sant lets that happen. "Good Will Hunting" is a 90s classic for all the right reasons and it's a lovely example of purely great filmmaking. Each filmic aspect comes together perfectly for a wonderful final product.
The acting is outstanding, and so is the direction (and the Academy-Award winning script), and all of this makes Good Will Hunting a film so good it is hard to describe in words.
I watched it when I was younger and didn't like it much, now that I'm older and more mature, you can now see how truly great this movie is.  Very well thought out and smart.

What will be forever known as "The movie that should have won Best Picture instead of Titanic" Good Will Hunting is American Drama at it's best. Simple, well-acted, with a story that everyone with an IQ of 70+ can understand.

Matt Damon, sporting his best attempt at a Dawson's Creek mid-90's haircut, plays Will, a disturbed genius born on the "wrong side of the tracks" and seems to not only accept his lot but embrace it. A life of menial construction and janitorial work, pub crawls, and fist fights with anyone who looks at you wrong. 

But as a janitor, will is under-stimulated. So he anonymously answers a super-tough math question posted in the hall by a math professor for his students. He gets discovered, and the math prof takes Will under his wing, the only problem being Will has court-ordered counselling after his most recent fist-fight. Enter Robin Williams, a hairy 5'3 beast as always, but his brain for once is not self-medicating itself with his own bodily-created methamphetamine...A geeky way of saying Robin Williams has settled down, and is great as a similarly-disturbed counselor.

Will and him form a special friendship that you believe. The movie is perhaps predictable, but it still holds your interest all the way through as Matt Damon and Ben Affleck's breakout movie. My favorite part besides Robin Williams (who thankfully won an oscar for this) is a great speech Ben Affleck makes near the end of the movie. Where he basically explains it's ok, it's cool if you're not super smart and have to live a simple blue-collar life: It's honorable, and it's OK, but IF, IF you have great creative potential you're robbing the world of a genious and robbing yourself of your destiny. Something I think is great advice.

The movie would be absolutely legendary and a 6/5 star movie (you read that right) if it wern't for Will's love interest played by a deftly annoying Minnie Driver. She's a flake with an annoying accent, cries all the time, and seems like the exact kind of girl a real world Will would reject. Or maybe that's just my opinion. I also wish they went more in-depth into Peter Skaarsgard's math prof...Who is extreamly driven and competitive to the point of needing therapy himself, in my opinion. But, the movie barely touches on that. Maybe time constraints?

Still, it's the best movie of 1997 hands down, and probably the best cultural piece of any medium to come out of 1997 as far as I know. Seriously, what else was there? Go watch it.

Matt

Matt Damon is Will Hunting, a Janitor at MIT with a hidden affinity for numeracy and mathematics. He has a troubled life and has never allowed himself to live up to his abilities. Will gets into a fight and he has to choose between a prison stretch or attending psychiatric therapy sessions. Pushed into a corner he opts for the sessions and meets Robin Williams' Sean Maguire. The film is an amazing look into the ever changing relationships Will has and with the new people he meets; his friends, psychiatrist and love interest played brilliantly by Minnie Driver are all put to the test as Will struggles with intimacy and relationships. The characters and dialogue are both rich and the film is simply a delight to watch. Kudos to Matt Damon and Ben Affleck who proved their credentials by writing the script. It's a wonderful, touching film full of talent and is surprisingly uplifting.

Once in a great while, I see a movie which has me amazed at the level of craft put into the research and development of the dialogue and characters. This movie did not have any special effects and yes, it did have 154 f-bombs, but all of the characters were thoroughly engaging and deep. The conversations were intelligent, full of facts and clever asides - just the sort of conversations I hope to have with people once I've read many, many more books and lived many, many more years.

Thereâ(TM)s something suspicious about the story here. Itâ(TM)s quite ironic that the film itself is easily comparable to its lead character. Its script often seems to keep running on and on, similar to how Damonâ(TM)s character speaks quickly in his sentences of interminable length; it doesnâ(TM)t seem to care what its own outcome is; and, worst of all, it doesnâ(TM)t seem to be moving in any specific direction. For quite a long time, the film consists of talky, in-depth explanations of the characters it details. Each character seemed to be studied to a certain depth, with Williamsâ(TM)s and Damonâ(TM)s characters being expounded upon greatly. It takes at least forty-five minutes for the premise to be officially established, where we first see Dr. Maguire start to work with Will. After that, the film spends its precious time trying to explain upon this premise, but the pacing is so slow that it ends up going a very short distance.

Perhaps the greatest relief GOOD WILL HUNTING had to offer was Williamsâ(TM)s performance. Watching him break away from his comedic comfort zone is like listening to Afrika Bambaataa try to yodel. Whatâ(TM)s even more odd (and impressive), he succeeds enormously. If there is one performance that makes this film watchable, itâ(TM)s that from Robin Williams. Iâ(TM)ll include mention that this opened up the careers of other recognizable names such as Ben Affleck and Matt Damon. Those two are impressive in their acting roles, but Williams is the one that seems to shine.

Hadn't seen this for ages and turned on the TV late this week to find it started. Didn't intend to watch it all but found myself enjoying it too much. It's funny to watch it now and think of the careers of the principal cast in the years after. Damon is now a bona fide star with great turns in 'Talented Mr Ripley', 'The Informant!' and 'True Grit' and of course the Borne films. Williams is still living off the Oscar he got for this role and is mixing poor comedies with some interesting dramatic choice ('One Hour Photo', 'Insomnia') and Affleck has gone from action knucklehead to renowned director. To be fair on all of them this film gives a clear indication where their careers were destined. Damon is outstanding in the lead role and brings a vulnerability to a character that on paper could be seen as very unlikable. Williams plays it straight and subdued and then lets rip with the baseball scene and his confrontations with Damon and Skarsgan. Affleck is good in the supporting role but brilliant in his last scene with Damon and his final moments waiting outside his door. He isn't the strongest actor here but he plays it well and the fact that he wrote the script with Damon shows that his talents were always going to be evident behind the camera too. The film still feels fresh today and even if some moments are a bit too 'Hollywood' (e.g. "It's not your fault") then the film can be forgiven for that. Damon and Affleck should write again.

Handled brilliantly by Gus Van Sant, Damon and Affleck's story of an unlikely genius' relationship with his shrink is a masterful drama that only gets better with repeat viewings. Aided by a fantastic cast, the film carries great dramatic weight, playing a subtle sentimentality against the hard-edged central performance from Damon (who has rarely been better). Other standout performances include a career best turn from Minnie Driver, the always reliable Stellan Skarsgard and the Oscar-winning work of Robin Williams.

Good Will Hunting is a great film with both fine and (necessary) coarse parts, superbly balanced with a great screenplay (by co-actors Matt Damon and Ben Affleck) and excellent performances. The narrative, while at times predictable or pretentious, is tough when it needs to and intimate when it should be, allowing the audience to see the unraveling/arc of both Damon's (a brilliantly-minded young man with a tough exterior, but troubling past) and Robin Williams's (a community college professor who has trouble forgetting the death of his wife) characters. Essentially, both characters must come to terms with their past, and while one is the therapist and the other the client, they require the help of each other to do so. It is because of this and the keen directorial eye Gus Van Sant that make the moments between these two exceptional yet stubborn men (my favorite being Williams's monologue by the lake) the heart and best scenes of the film. The supporting cast, with their own problems and realizations, as well as their influences on Damon's character, are well-rounded and well-performed as well. There is motivation to be found in the story and script as well as some funny and quirky moments that pull the film together nicely. Good Will Hunting is a different kind of uplifting and charming film, and it is all the more better for it.

GWH is undoubtedly one of the finest movies to have ever graced the silver screen. A brilliantly written story and screenplay from Matt Damon (mostly) and his far less-intelligent childhood chum Ben Affleck. She is the only reason this movie isn't perfect. However, Minnie's annoying accent, and veritable paucity of acting talent is insufficient to prevent me from giving this movie its proper rating: 5 stars. One of the best of all time.

Unlikely screenwriters-turned-actors (or is it the other way around?) Damon and Affleck managed to pen one of the most critically acclaimed films of all time.  The script deserved its Oscar as did Robin Williams who won for Best Supporting Actor.  Williams' father-figure relationship with Damon (who deservedly received an Oscar nod) is heartwarming as he tries to help Damon to reach his potential and, more importantly, find happiness.  The film is worth watching just for one of Damon's incredible intellectual monologues.  Minnie Drive also earned an Oscar for the role that is undoubtedly the best that she has portrayed (or ever will).  The story is simple: A troubled college-age kid with potential that is hindered by his baggage meets a man who can help.  The thing that makes this film special is its South Boston atmosphere and was the first in a long line of films that would use this gritty atmosphere to create a portrait of "tough" American life.  If you are interested in action and special effects, this is not your film; however, if you are looking for a raw portrayal of life and a script that will transport you to South Boston, few films will impress you more.

"So if I asked you about art, you'd probably give me the skinny on every art book ever written. Michelangelo, you know a lot about him. Life's work, political aspirations, him and the pope, sexual orientations, the whole works, right? But I'll bet you can't tell me what it smells like in the Sistine Chapel. You've never actually stood there and looked up at that beautiful ceiling; seen that. If I ask you about women, you'd probably give me a syllabus about your personal favorites. You may have even been laid a few times. But you can't tell me what it feels like to wake up next to a woman and feel truly happy. You're a tough kid. And I'd ask you about war, you'd probably throw Shakespeare at me, right, "once more unto the breach dear friends." But you've never been near one. You've never held your best friend's head in your lap, watch him gasp his last breath looking to you for help. I'd ask you about love, you'd probably quote me a sonnet. But you've never looked at a woman and been totally vulnerable. Known someone that could level you with her eyes, feeling like God put an angel on earth just for you. Who could rescue you from the depths of hell. And you wouldn't know what it's like to be her angel, to have that love for her, be there forever, through anything, through cancer. And you wouldn't know about sleeping sitting up in the hospital room for two months, holding her hand, because the doctors could see in your eyes, that the terms "visiting hours" don't apply to you. You don't know about real loss, 'cause it only occurs when you've loved something more than you love yourself. And I doubt you've ever dared to love anybody that much. And look at you... I don't see an intelligent, confident man... I see a cocky, scared shitless kid. But you're a genius Will. No one denies that. No one could possibly understand the depths of you. But you presume to know everything about me because you saw a painting of mine, and you ripped my fucking life apart."

This story is about a young and rebellious janitor Will Hunting (Matt Damon) from South Boston working at MIT school in Cambridge, but unbeknownst to anyone except his friends Will is a self educated genius. Smarter even than MIT's shining star professor and Fields Medal winner Dr. Gerald Lambeau (Stellan Skarsgård), Will catches the attention of Dr. Lambeau when he secretly solves a math formula at work one night that only a handful of people could solve. Eager to work with this young genius after tracking him down, Dr. Lambeau finds out he is a rebellious young man who's facing jail time after a street fight escalates into Will hitting a police officer. So young will is given a free pass on the condition he work with the Professor and see a therapist, but the only therapist that has a chance of getting close to the hard edged and guarded genius is Dr. Lambeau's old college roommate Sean McGuire (Robin Williams).
This is a solid plot with great acting and very good character development about this young genius who has to face some painful memories from his dark past if he wants any chance of breaking free from his suffocating and dead end lifestyle. Opening old wounds, he begins to take chances in life and work through his trust issues.

This is a classic and one of my all time favourite movies. Matt Damon's performance as the young genius janitor was superb. In order to avoid jail time, He is taken under the wing of a professor at the University and he assists him with mathematical equations. As part of his conditions he also has to see a psychiatrist. Will Hunting (matt Damon) does everything within his power to avoid seeing a psychiatrist and his antics are quite humorous. When he meets Robin Williams he attempts to scare him away but after numerous sessions where Robin Williams does not leave they begin to form their relationships which is quite entertaining and heart pulling at the same time. This film was actually somewhat difficult to comprehend. It was so intelligent and mature in its nature that it was ahead of my mind somehow.
The character that Matt Damon played, Will Hunting - the mathematics genius, was a very overbearing being to me and he showed that it is hard to choose what you want when you don't know what you want. He had this amazing gift, but it meant nothing to him because all he wanted was what he left to leave him for California, his girlfriend played by Minnie Driver.
Robin Williams plays a community college professor who becomes Will's therapist who finally is able to connect with Will after five other therapists. Robin Williams is a great actor. He was a great comedic actor but will forever be a great dramatic actor. There is no surprise that Williams won the Oscar for best supporting actor, the other guys didn't stand a chance.
And of course this film won for best original screenplay. Its only competition in the list was As Good As It Gets and that didn't even stand a chance.
This film was really good and the acting was fabulous, except for maybe Ben Affleck, but that's no surprise.
The story, the acting, and the character development are most likely the best parts of this film.
Good Will Hunting, I give you an 80%.

Most people know this movie which made quite a stir when it first appeared and deservedly so. I was never particularly interested in the story of the janitor who is a mathematical genius but always finds ways to push people away and desires to sink to a common, comfortable level of life. It is a fine movie and well worth all the praise.

It also increased my appreciation of Matt Damon's acting skills. Having first come across him in the Bourne trilogy, I had little to judge the breadth of his skill as that role called for one note, though he played that note very well. Then having seen him star (brilliantly) in The Informant, my estimation of him shot sky high. I have since enjoyed his comic skills as a guest on 30 Rock and this view of his early talent was a pleasure to behold. What a talent!

"Issues: The Movie". Supposedly you can create an Oscar-worthy film by giving nearly every major character daddy issues and having them all spew inspirational dialogue.  Good Will Hunting is a cliched, mediocre, overrated film.  I was honestly shocked and disappointed when I watched this movie.  
It is hard to claim a film is genius when it literally explains every single element needlessly and relentlessly.  Seriously, do major characters need to explain why an orphan would have abandonment issues when the film has spent its entirety establishing that, yes, Will Hunting has abandonment issues.
The performances were okay, with the exception of Ben Affleck's "performance", but I was surprised to find out that Minnie Driver was nominated for an Oscar since her performance was merely "meh".  Speaking of Oscars, this film won for "Best Writing (Original Screenplay)" and was praised for its "original and realistic dialogue".  While some of the dialogue was above average, I found many moments where I actually laughed out loud, such as the climax of the film.  
I was expecting something better than this, even Van Sant's directing was just okay.  The film oozes predictability (just watch any other inspirational film from the 90s) and the cliches piled up so fast that it almost felt like the film was a self-aware satire of inspirational films.

A viewing of this movie has been a long time coming. I wasn't blown away for several reasons, but I still really liked it. The acting is great across the board, and the script has the kind of raw talent that we like to associate with Ben Affleck (when we aren't remembering his sucky turnouts). On top of that, this movie didn't feel annoyingly Boston-ish, like some of - sorry, all of - the recent movies in Boston have. Gus Van Sant has a peculiar style about him, but he's got great focus, and he does a great job bringing out things like intimacies and themes. Mostly, my problems were with the characters themselves, in that most of them, like Will, would change their demeanor instantly at the flip of a switch. It isn't so much a problem for Will's buddies because they fight all the time, though that got to be pretty tiring after a while, but instead for characters like the teacher and the girlfriend. Will and the teacher are brats, Will's cronies are morons, and his lady friend is chronically underdeveloped, so we start cheering for Robin Williams' character by default. Successfully helping Will would be a great success story, but it would also shut him up and make him mature, and I think I was rooting for both of these equally.

Poignant, human, and overwhelmingly emotional, 'Good Will Hunting' is a beautifully crafted story of a troubled young genius. Impeccably written by stars Matt Damon and Ben Affleck, 'Good Will Hunting' is held aloft by a pitch-perfect script, accurately depicting the life of young South-Bostonian men, the internal conflict of each and every main character, and the internal strife of a brilliant young man. Equally impressive are the performances, where every single member of the cast gives magnificent performances, Williams above all, to escalate 'Good Will Hunting' to a level rarely matched by any drama seen in film.

Final Grade: A+

Will Hunting (Matt Damon) is a janitor at M.I.T. and he has a brain that is unusually brilliant in such things as math and chemistry, though he has no clue just how smart he is. A math professor finds out about Will's gift, and tries desperately to get him to leave his small town neighborhood, and make a name for himself in the world. But the professor needs help, so he asks an old friend named Sean Maguire (Robin Williams), who is also currently a teacher, to assist in getting Will's life on track. Meanwhile, for the first time ever, Will is falling in love and is trying to live his own life, rejecting any help offered.

There's nothing too original to say about Good Will Hunting, as everyone who sees it basically ends up spouting out the same stuff. It's a brilliant film, a masterpiece really. It's one of those movies that I could watch on a weekly basis. It's intelligent, it has huge heart, it's funny, it's sad, it's entertaining, and it's about as close to perfection, when it comes to filmmaking, as you can get. This was the movie that allowed Gus Van Sant to take his career where he wanted to, and that makes it an even more special achievement.

Will Hunting works as a janitor at one of the most prestigious schools in the country, M.I.T. When a professor puts a virtually impossible to solve problem up on the chalk board outside of his classroom, Will solves it. The professor tracks him down and gets him out of some legal trouble. All he has to do to avoid jail is work with the professor with math and go to counseling. He's fine with the math, but hates the idea of counseling. As the story goes on he meets a girl and we slowly learn why he is so stuck in the position in life that he is and why he is unwilling and unable to use his unique skill.

What hits you right off the bat with this film is how smooth the dialogue flows, and that's a testament to the writing of Ben Affleck and Matt Damon, who just won an Oscar for Best Screenplay. Then the performances hit you. Damon is phenomenal. Stellan Skasgard is great, even Affleck and Minnie Driver are really good. But everyone knows that Robin Williams steals the show and also, justly, wins a best supporting actor Oscar for his turn as Sean, Will's counselor. Van Sant's direction is also good, but with a screenplay like this and actors on top of their game, it makes it a lot easier.

If you're one of the five people who haven't seen this film, you definitely need to. It's one of those must see movies. It's hard to describe just how good the film is with words, you just need to see it to truly know.

Yeah, it's strange watching a movie so many people have already seen and that you've heard so much about. Granted, my expectations for "Good Will Hunting" weren't big; what amount of something's got to give to make a feel-good story about a troubled genius and the MIT professor and psychologist fighting for his mind's right to party really pop? The answer: not a lot. It's boiler plate as the Danny Elfman score playing over it; Robin Williams seems to be borrowing a little too obviously from his character in "Dead Poets Society"; and Ben Affleck and Matt Damon winning an Oscar in '98 for original screenplay over Paul Thomas Anderson for "Boogie Nights"? Give me a break. 

Nonetheless "Good Will Hunting" enjoyably yarns the tale of exactly that, a smart and silenced kid with a head full of scattered ideas and a heart tripped in paranoia. There's no denying Affleck and Damon's sentiment toward "Good Will Hunting's" screen troupers, and the dedication at letting you walk out with a smile on your face.

This is an emotional movie about how frustrating it can be to watch intelligence go to waste. A truly brilliant mind is discovered in an unlikely place, a blue-collar janitor with absolutely no ambition. It is very hard to watch as his lack of drive and underachieving friends land in him bad situations. Everyone around the troubled genius pushes him to pursue a better life and use his gift, but it is not easy. It is a rough haul trying to get through his troubled past, extreme insecurity, and short temper. Matt Damon and Robin Williams are simply amazing. Skarsgard, Driver, Affleck and the rest of the supporting cast are good but Williams and Damon truly make the movie. The characters and dialogue are really enhanced by the great acting. These are such strong characters and the story is compelling as well. It is a noteworthy and memorable movie that I highly recommend.

Good Will Hunting has gotten a bit of flack over the years; it's one of those movies that captured everyone's attention and affection upon being released, but in the years since, has been stuck with the stigma of being an undeserving object of adoration.  Perhaps it's because the film seems to hit every Oscar-baity note perfectly, or because the actors have gone on to careers that don't often match the heights of this great film.  Whatever the reason is, Good Will Hunting is still a captivating watch, and it's hard to heed the criticism when a film is such a satisfying package.

Ben Affleck and Matt Damon's Oscar-winning screenplay put them on the map, and for good reason.  While the story is simply, the characters within it are beautifully drawn out, especially the titular Will Hunting (Damon) and his mentor, Sean Maguire (Robin Williams in a career-best performance).  Some of the supporting characters come off as caricatures, but if anything, they provide some welcome comic relief from the film's more dramatic moments.

Williams' performance is one for the ages.  The typically comic actor does so well when given a meatier dramatic role to tackle, and Good Will Hunting provides him with his finest part to date.  Williams still has a slyness in line with much of his other work, but he also perfectly communicates the pain of loss, his faith in Will, and a general caring nature.  His scenes with Damon represent the film at its very best; the chemistry, whether they're arguing or finally forging an emotional connection, is fantastic.  Their relationship serves as the heart of a truly great, and very deservedly celebrated, modern classic.

A great performance by an actor is always a welcome addition to any movie. Witnessing true chemistry between stars, however, is even more rewarding. The focus seems to shift  from the talents of individual rolls and rather to an intangible beauty that is created by the interactions of distinctive characters. Such is a rare and welcome occurrence indeed, and I was happy to see 'Good Will Hunting' accomplish such a feat. 

The film follows the life of an amazingly gifted young man named Will Hunting. Will, played by Matt Damen, works as a janitor at the prestigious MIT school in Boston Mass. The irony of his position at the college surfaces when a highly decorated mathematics teacher discovers Will's talents for solving equations that only a hand full of people in the world could decipher. When the professor approaches him to discuss his talents, he discovers that Will hardly fits the description of a typical genius scholar. Fascinated further by his conflicted personality but unable to break through the boy's defensive nature, Professor Lambeau employs the talents of a old colleague and psychologist Sean Maguire (Robin Williams, who received an Oscar for this work) to help Will find a direction for his life that will allow him to realize his full potential. 

It is at this point where the film enjoys a breath of new life. When Damen and Williams exchange banter on screen, it is both entertaining and magical. I was extremely impressed at how well Damen was able to keep up with the seasoned Robin Williams. They effortlessly reinforce each others characters as the dialogue amongst them ensues. Though they lead contrasting lives, an uneasy respect is formed by their curious commonalities and views of the world. Through sharing their pains and triumphs alike, the two unearth past issues that have impacted them both deeply. 

My fascination with these two stands as the highlight of the film. This is not to say that I was entirely disappointed with the remainder of the cast, but they served more as indicators of Will's progression rather than individual sub stories. When he corresponds with his love interest or friends, it offers little beyond a peak into the complexities of his personality and where the therapy is taking him. Alone, this may seem like a meager contribution from an actor, but they remain a necessary piece of the puzzle. 

The only marked exception to this circumstance is the sarcastic exchanges that Professor Lambeau and Sean enjoy throughout the film. There is a playful tension between the two that offers enough charm to remain a pleasant diversion from Will's journey.

With so much invested in the maturity of Will and Sean's relationship and into unraveling Will's multifaceted persona, some other aspects of the movie do suffer somewhat. Scenes begin to feel a little rushed near the climax, as if the director panicked to tie up every loose end. This caused the intensity of the story to flicker a bit. However, as hurried as these scenes may feel, the final act does offer a fitting resolution that should leave most audiences satisfied. 

Ultimately, the strength lies within the for mentioned chemistry that transpires. Without this brilliance I believe the film would have fallen flat. When the two are apart, the script begins to lose its luster. There are no amazing plot twists, no catastrophic turn of events, but rather a story that probes into facets of aspirations and the desire for purpose of life. Such a tale demands a high calabur of artistic execution by its leads to outshine the movies weaknesses, and 'Good Will Hunting' does just that. 

Rating: 8 out of 10

A very moving story from then-novice filmmakers and writers Damon and Affleck.  A fantastic performance from Robin Williams, much more restrained than many of his roles, yet with an underlying passion in the character that is important to the story.  This story of a mis-understood mathematical genius (Damon) is, in some ways, similar to Amadeus, which I recently reviewed.  The difference is that while Amadeus is told from the perspective of the people around the genius who can only marvel at his abilities, Good Will Hunting is told more from the perspective of the genius and his struggles to belong to the world instead of be set apart from it.  Unlike Amadeus's Mozart, Will Hunting is not arrogant or self-serving, although he doesn't shy away from telling people how good he is.  But he's so afraid of failure that he won't push himself.  The story is perhaps a little too pat and the ending is expected, but the performances make up for these minor shortcomings.

5 out of 5 stars. Good Will Hunting is an excellent drama about a 20 year old named Will Hunting who is played by Matt Damon. Will has a long record of getting into trouble with the law, while downplaying and hiding the fact that he is a genius in the area of mathematics.  Instead of going to jail for assaulting a police officer, the judge agrees to allow Will to leave under the care of a math professor as long as Will meets the conditions of working on difficult math problems with this new mentor of his, and that Will visits regularly with a psychologist.  At first, Will does everything he can to avoid therapy, but he begins to open up more once he meets a counselor named Sean, who is played by Robin Williams. Will gradually begins to understand the importance of accepting himself and the past experiences who have made Will who he is in present day, as well as learning to take risks to allow new people into his life. In the past Will has learned to push people away before they have a chance of hurting him or letting him down. Through his counseling sessions, Will begins to accept the fact that he needs to open up to others so he can start to experience parts of life that he has been missing.

Literally one of the best films of the past twenty years. By now the story is Hollywood legend but the story by Damon and Affleck is just incredible. It is smart, crisp and balanced. There is a perfect juxtaposition of comedy, heartfelt moments and moments that make you cringe. There are at least four or five moments that make you either laugh hysterically or cry your heart out. Much of the credit here can be attributed to solid performances by all involved but some masterful work by Driver and Williams. Driver in particular is amazing to watch. I had forgotten how moving she is in the role of Skylar. On the production side the score and soundtrack to the film are just great and the sound mixing between the two just resonates. I like the choices Van Sant makes with his camera, what he got form his actors, just everything. And of course, the role of the narrative in showing us what our lives can be speaks volumes. The role that Williams plays, showing us that it is our choices that define us, that we should follow our hearts. Wow. I just hope that one day I am lucky enough to have to go "see about a girl".

Matt Damon's and Ben Affleck's well crafted script is hugely enjoyable to watch and absorb. The storyline itself may seem a little "fairytale", (boy brought up in a foster home but is an academic genius), but Damon and Affleck have worked hard to avoid clichés and a typical ending.

The strength in Good Will Hunting is all down to the screenplay and the performances from the actors. Damon is excellent and Affleck is equally as good. Damon manages to come across as very charming and likeably almost instantly rather than a boy who sits around feeling sorry for himself. On the other hand Damon might seem a little "pretty-boy" for someone who has been abused in several foster homes but Damon's acting makes you forget all that as he comes across very threatening and violent, in particular "the break-up " scene. This just shows what a great actor Matt Damon is. Robin William's is outstanding, especially in the scenes with Damon and his rival, (the college professor who discovered Hunting in prison0, played superbly by Stellan Skarsguard. From the begging there is a clear link and similarity to Will Hunting and William's character which the two actors portray on screen with real emotion and reality.

The director, Gus Van Sant, quite rightly chooses to avoid any soppy and unnecessary sentimental value just for the audience's sake, but instead finds real human emotion within the harsh story of Will's upbringing but never goes too overboard with the details. The film provides both heart and humour, in particular the friends Will hangs around with as there is a great chemistry between all four of them and some very funny banter dialogue.

Danny Elfman's score fits perfectly with the backdrop of Harvard and the city of Boston. It creates a sense of security and calmness. With dramatic scenes there is no music which shows how powerful the actor's performances are as the scenes are still very effective. This shows Van Sant's clever choice to show off his actors and how he respects their performances.

Good Will Hunting is a fantastic movie with an amazing script, elegant direction and magnificent performances. Scripts like this do not get written very often and Damon and Affleck have written a masterpiece which will be studied by all who wish to write the perfect movie screenplay.
