Good Will Hunting is a solid, by-the-book, underdog tearjerker. Matt Damon stars as Will Hunting, a prodigy hoodlum whose life is going nowhere fast. After a playground brawl, he ends up in the hands of Dr. Sean Maguire (Oscar-winner Robin Williams), and together, they allow Will to embrace his genius and connect with people despite a troubled past. Minnie Driver, Ben Affleck, Stellan Skarsgard, and Casey Affleck round out a very good ensemble. Despite some excellent acting (especially from Damon, Williams, and Driver), moments of great writing (the film was written by--and won Oscars for--Damon and Ben Affleck themselves), and being very easy to watch, Good Will Hunting left me slightly cold. The popular appeal is there, though, and it's certainly not a bad film.

Good Will Hunting is the Academy Award winning film written by Matt Damon and Ben Affleck and it was vividly and artistically directed by Gus Van Sant. The brilliant cast includes Matt Damon, Ben Affleck, Robin Williams, Minnie Driver, and Stellan Skarsgard. The premise is rather simple, it follows a trouble genius who forms an unexpected and important friendship with his psychiatrist who tries to help him find his way in life. The Academy Award winning screenplay is precise and brilliant featuring well written characters, clever dialogue, and a truly solid story structure. Good Will Hunting is not only one of the best movies of 1997, but you could also make the argument that it is one of the finest movies ever made.

The performances are absolutely incredible. Matt Damon's complex and witty performance as Will Hunting almost steals the show. He absolutely takes control of all of the movie's toughest scenes. His performance is unexpectedly moving and heartfelt. The reason why I say ALMOST steals the show is because of the amazing precense of Robin Williams. Together the two form a bizzare and unique friendship and they generate solid chemistry. The best scenes of the movie are when Williams and Damon are just yakking at eachother. It's brilliant. The supporting cast helps here a lot as well though too. Affleck is almost non-existent, but his character is important to the story's final arc, so I give credit to the writing more than him. Casey Affleck adds some unexpected and unusual comic relief in an extremely small role. The gorgeous Minnie Driver is great as Damon's potential "soulmate" and her character Skylar is another extremely brilliantly written character. Finally, Stellan Skarsgard's small but pivotal role is great as well. 

This is one of my favorite movies of all-time. It's a very moving and touching portrait about a troubled man and it offers a lot of vivid and interesting outlooks on life and the direction in which we all choose to take. I admire the smart and relaxed direction by Van Sant, who just let his actors act and he lets the dialogue and the characters take over the film, which evokes some serious emotion. This film had a profound effect on me. After I saw it, I literally could not get the film out of my head. The characters and the dialogue stuck with me. That's when you know you've got a truly amazing and classic film on your hands.

Good Will Hunting is a masterpiece.

A heartfelt story that is masterfully acted by all in its cast. Robin Williams and Matt Damon are a tremendous duo that feed off eachother to make the emotions flow freely and purely. Kudos to Affleck and Damon on the script. One of my personal favorite movies of all time. 100/100

Male bonding has always been a matter of subtle expression.. however, a film made solely from those contained little moments would surely result in themes of repressed homosexuality which Good Will Hunting, although directed by openly gay filmmaker Gus Van Sant, seeks to avoid. The connections made between men in the movie almost always come reluctantly, though heightened melodrama helps to clarify and make all too apparent the significance of these moments to the characters development. This may come across this day and age as somewhat trite and or predictably sentimental as it all builds to the obvious enlightening of the Will Hunting character, but what makes the movie as good as it is are the details in Vant Sant's delicate handling of each character in the film and his ability to balance out every moment to enrich the personalities of everyone in the story. In the end, we care about these people.. and in a movie dealing with such "thoughtful" material, giving equal emotional weight is no small accomplishment.

The other extremely notable theme in the film I've always appreciated belongs to the mathematician's character, who although very much an intelligent and gifted individual on his own terms, cannot live up to the natural abilities of the young prodigy. His emotional low at the end of the second act is inadvertently a 'high' point of the film.

This movie receives some critisim for being predictable.  I agree that it is fairly predictable, but that is really beside the point.  Watching this movie is like walking through an art gallery, you can't spend the whole time thinking about the next painting or that ruins the experience.  Instead you have to enjoy the masterpiece before you down to the little nuances, like how every single line is in character.  The script is geniously written, it's perfectly cast and every actor provides a good to great perfomance.  The directing recognizes that these are the greatest strengths of the movie and puts them on the forefront keeping the focus on the dialogue and just allowing the actors to simply act.  A movie made this well doesn't need to rely on such a cheap thrill as suspense.

Emotional, powerful, very well written, Good Will Hunting will not let you down. That's all you need to know.

Will Hunting (Matt Damon)is a college janitor who is a genius in mathematics, only no one knows it. Being brought up in a rough childhood, from foster home to foster home, Will is hanging out with his best friends: Chuckie Sullivan (Ben Affleck), Billy Mcbride (Cole Hauser), and Morgan O'Mally (Casey Affleck). His friends basically go to a bar everyday and get drunk. Will doesn't mind but he gets into a lot of fights throughout his life.

One day, he is caught doing an impossible math equation that took the professor, who put it on the chalkboard, two years to complete. They soon find out about his past history as he has been arrest for assaults, grand theft auto, and hitting a police officer the past couple of years. They get him out of jail under a couple of conditions: he helps the professors with math problems and sees a psychiatrist.

He sort of blows off the first five therapists he meets until he sees Sean Maguire (Robin Williams), a respectable man who is facing hardships from his wife passing away two years prior. Together, they try to figure out Will's past and future by decreasing his violent moods and try to understand that he is a genius and different from most people.

Good Will Hunting is fantastic. Even though it is a basic story, truly remarkable performances from Matt Damon (nominated for role) and Robin Williams (Won Academy Award for this role), perfect writing by Matt Damon and Ben Affleck (Won Academy Award in this category), and great directing from Mr. Van Sant truly make Good Will Hunting a near perfect film.

Matt Damon and Ben Affleck both won an Oscar for their work on this screenplay, but everyone knows that. Its written from the point of view of someone who actually grew up in Boston, and already had enough experiences for a lifetime. Its so powerfully written and well directed and is deserving of all its praise.

Its the story of a gifted young adult, Will (Matt Damon), who works as a janitor at MIT and is able to solve extremely difficult math equations left undone. One of the professors sees his talents and tries to mold him into a scholar instead of what he is- a bum.  He ends up beating the hell out of some seemingly random kids on the basketball court and is forced to complete counseling or else be thrown in jail. His counselor is Robin Williams and he really affects Will as a person and gets him to see the world differently- essentially helping him grow up. Once he completes his counseling sessions he is left to find a job, of which he has many offers. His choice lets the audience into Will for the first time and we see what is truly important to him and how mature he has become.

About halfway into the movie I started to become worried- there was no conflict set up yet, and although it was clever and funny it didnt have any dynamic quality. But then I realized that the main conflict wasnt between two people, but within Will. He has all this potential and can do anything with his life that he wants, but he doesnt want it. Its the characters around him that must shape his final decision.

Matt Damon was terrific as the lead, although you could tell at times that he was still a bit raw as an actor. And if Damon was terrific then Robin Williams was immaculate in his role. He was required to play off Damon and match his passion and energy level- and I think he beat them. He definitely deserved his Oscar here, even though I really dont like him as an actor otherwise. Other notable performers here were the Affleck Bros. with my favorite being Ben. Ben Affleck is actually a very talented individual and it is clearly evident in this movie. Direction here was also very good, Gus Van Sant does an excellent job making the script come alive but I think is very much overshadowed by the other aspects of the film.

Definitely my new favorite movie and Ill end my review with my favorite quote from the film, its Ben Affleck talking to Matt Damon about his future, and how he can do better.

Chuckie (Ben Affleck):  Every day I come by your house and I pick you up. And we go out. We have a few drinks, and a few laughs, and it's great. But you know what the best part of my day is? For about ten seconds, from when I pull up to the curb and when I get to your door, 'cause I think, maybe I'll get up there and I'll knock on the door and you won't be there. No goodbye. No see you later. No nothing. You just left. I don't know much, but I know that.

This is without a doubt one of the best movies ever made. Everybody that stars in this movie is fantastic, including Ben Affleck. Director Gus Van Zant who directed "Drugstore Cowboy," and "Milk," has made without a doubt one of the best movies of the 1990's. It's such an emotional and wonderful movie to watch that it sticks with you the moment your done watching it. Matt Damon in my opinion gives the best performance of his career in this movie playing Will Hunting, the genius kid from South Boston who solves the big math equation that Stellan Skarsgard's character leaves in the hallway for his the students to solve to only have it mysteriously solved by Damon's character who happens to be the janitor of the college he works at. But for me it's really Robin Williams that sticks out the most for me just because it's Robin freakin' Williams, who gives in my opinion a career defining performance as the therapist that tries to help counsel Damon's character in order to keep him out of jail for getting into a brawl with Affleck and the rest of the crew against these Italians that hang out in the South Boston area and hits a cop in the process of being pulled back from almost beating one of the Italian guys to death. It's a very human performance, one that makes this one very different from all the other performances he has done on screen. It's the one that definitely made him worth of the best supporting oscar that year in 1997. Sure he cracks some good jokes here and there in the film, but he never shies away from his dramatic side through out the movie. Williams has played a lot of great characters on screen, but when I think about which one is my favorite, this performance is the first one to enter my head. I can't say enough about his performance because it felt so real to me the whole time, especially when he goes into talking to Damon's character about his wife who in the film has been dead for two years, but you can clearly see he is still grieving from the loss. And could you blame him? I mean for a man who loved his wife as much as he did in this movie you can see how hard it would be for a person like William's character to move on with his life. It's really when him and Damon really get into it in one therapy session about what Damon's character wants to do with his life and he can't give Williams character a straight answer and when tries to kick Damon out of the therapy session, that's when Damon confronts him and tells him that even though he lost a big hand that some people after losing a big hand like that have the sack to get back up and try again...and he's right. Both men are very compelling in the film and what makes the movie so great is the interaction between Damon and Williams that through the therapy sessions, both men learn to heal and move on with their lives, that's what makes the movie so great. I literally balled my eyes out when I was watching the movie last night with my sister at the scene when Williams character tells Damon that it's not his fault to what happened to him as a foster child, but Damon's character doesn't want to hear it, but Williams keeps pursuing Damon to realize that it is not your fault that were abused it was the asshole foster father that is to blame for beating him. And what makes it so great is that at one point Damon gets defensive and pushes Williams away telling him not to fuck with him, but Williams doesn't let down and keeps telling him it's not your fault. And when the two men finally embrace each other and hug it out it's truly a work of art, and in that scene Gus Van Zant definitely deserved the best director nomination for the movie. Such a compelling scene that I'm almost feeling the emotions as I'm writing this. This is a movie that will live on through the ages, and it should, because this is a movie that hits you where it hits best...right in the heart.
Masterfully written and acted, "Good Will Hunting" is a captivating, honest and intelligent movie that's well directed by Gus Van Zant.

It's like the original "A Beautiful Mind", partially because, like Russell Crowe, Matt Damon's acting peak's with this film. No, he's not bad in everything after this film; he was just never given material a big as this, and that's a shame, because he is a heck of an actor, as we can see here, where he has to take on the challenging task of acting like he's from Boston. Yeah, I know he's a Bostonite, but even if - nay - especially if you're from the part of Boston he's from, it's hard to go back, and boy, Matt's boyfriend, Ben will probably never let us forget that, because he built his entire career around his scorn. Seriously Ben, get over it like your buddy has, because he's played a cowboy, a Grimm brother, a CIA officer, a butt-kicking spy, a southern lawyer, a god and, heck, even a cartoon horse; but after this film, he's never gone back to Boston, except for "The Departed", and even then, he ended up...- well, I'll just leave you to see that terrible ending to such a really good film yourself. Hey, if you ask me, Damon should probably go back to Boston more often, because that is where he comes out with some of his best work, whether it be the aforementioned "The Departed", or this film. Seriously, the score, the subject matter and even the title all come together to form this: ...cheesiness. I mean, it's still a really good film, but man, this film is so cheesy that even the color overlay on the poster is yellow.

Okay, so the film isn't terribly cornball, but there is a degree of sentimentality exacerbated by Elfman's sappy score, as well as formula in the story. The film isn't terribly formulaic, but neither is it too hard to predict where it's going, because the storyline is still so familiar, and yet, we still don't know enough about our characters. Okay, to be fair, at least the characters have some twists to them to make them unique, yet we don't get to see those twists right away, as the film is lacking in immediate development. Sure, we get to know them after a while, but mostly through expendable scenes of casualty, and while they don't overuse use those moments of casualty to the point of summoning disengagement, let alone tedium, but it certainly slows down the film. Really, I believe the problem to be Gus Van Sant's direction, which doesn't seem to fit the high intellegence of the screenplay. I mean, his direction isn't in the least terrible, nor does it even damage the film a whole lot, but he's such a sentimental storyteller handed a script that requires a director competent enough to provide emotional resonance, as well as a strong aura of sophistication, and while Van Sant's direction is still "just" smart enough, leaving the tone of the film to sometimes feel rather inconsistent. However, again, it's not like Van Sant is totally destroying the film, for although this film could have easily been better in the hands of a sentimental, as well as highly intellectual director, Van Sant's tone is "just" smart enough for you to feel most of the beats of Damon and Affleck's screenplay, and really, a "just smart enough" execution is alright with me, because no matter how low this film sinks on the rarest of occasions, you never forget that Damon and Affleck won that screenplay Oscar for a reason.

As I said earlier, Damon and Affleck tread familiar ground in the writing department, but don't dwell on the conventions of this storyline too much, keeping it slick enough to the point of not being terribly refreshing, yet still sharp enough for you to overlook the predictability. It certainly helps that the dialogue that Damon and Affleck have prepared is pretty darn sharp, whether when it comes to dealing with just some good ol' fashion, leave you chuckling snappy lines and back-and-forths, or portraying most of our characters in a believable fashion, particularly our lead character, Will Hunting, who's extreme level intellegence is most certainly made palpable by his cleverness and plenty of knowlege to back him up, yet he's not over-the-top, neither as a genius or a troubled mind, for the writers have found a perfect balance between the two defining attributes to our lead to make him totally believable as a human: flawed, believable and generally compelling. Speaking of Matt Damon, when I said that this might be his best performance, I wasn't just blowing smoke, because he is killing it dead in this role, bringing in his classic charisma at its sharpest, while seamlessly blending it with a subtle, yet tangible presence that boasts wit, as well as repressed anguish, creating a captivating level of humanity that comes into particularly sharp play when he works off of his fellow castmates, because whether he's hanging out with his chums or going through the motions of his budding romance with Minnie Driver, Damon forms electric chemistry with everyone. However, the chemistry that's most significant is the one between Damon and Robin Williams, and let me tell you, they sold it, put the money in the lottery, won, started a small business where they sold their chemistry, expanded that business, then started a chain of stores that sold their chemistry all across America, then Canada, then the UK, and eventually, three-fourths of the globe. As our leads' comradery builds, the level of compellingness in the film intensifies, as well, and watching the Damon and Williams orchestrate this dance of self-realization and friendship is hypnotic, yet wouldn't be nearly as effective if it wasn't for Gus Van Sant. No, Van Sant wasn't the perfect directing choice for this, but what he lacks in fulfilling the screenplay's level of intellegence, he makes up for by fulfilling it's emotional resonance, because, as I said, he is a very sentimental director, and one strong enough to really sell the heart of this film. For me, that golden moment where everyone running this machine - the writers, the leads and the director - all come together in one powerful moment is the climactic "It's not your fault" scene that's so heavily-written, so superbly-acted and so emotionally impacting (Forget it, I cry every time I see the scene), really tying everything together and paving the way for a satisfying conclusion to a film that may not fully live up to greatness, but still leaves you touched.

At the end of "Hunting" season, you're left looking back at this predictable, sentimental and rather intellectually inconsistent experiment, not minding the flaws, for what ultimately prevails is Matt Damon and Ben Affleck's very clever, very human script that is intensified by emotionally striking direction by Gus Van Sant, but most of all, the powerful performances and chemistry between Matt Damon and Robin Williams, both of whom provide the slickness, emotion and compellingness that carries "Good Will Hunting" from beginning to end.

Matt Damon is a janitor Will Hunting who's discovered to be a mathematical genius. Will has had a very abusive childhood which hurt him mentally to a point where he can no longer let anyone be close to him aside from his best friend played by Ben Affleck. Robin Williams later comes in as a therapist to Will, he is the only one who can really stand up to Will's intellect and manages to break the layer of distrust that Will has developed over years of solitude, and the two develop a bond beyond friendship.

Who would have thought that such an intelligent script to the movie was written by Matt and Ben themselves. The writing is witty, brilliant and hilarious at times. Both Matt and Robin Williams perform wonderfully in their roles. Matt Damon in particular was great as the complex Will Hunting - a genius at maths but a bit of an idiot in human relationships. His rough-edged exterior is simply a cry for help in which Robin Williams' character Sean Maguire does to best to do. Overall this movie is a good production, with solid craftsmanship in all departments -- thanks to the creativity of Damon and Affleck.

Superb film all round. Star (and career making turn) from Matt Damon as the hugely flawed janitor/maths genius ably supported by an arguably career best performance from an Oscar winning Robin Williams. Supporting cast is truly superb as well. Minnie Driver is adorable and she makes the audience adore her after only two short scenes, special stuff and I'll never forget her joke that's told like a pro stand up comedian. Stellan Skarsgard is great in a difficult role to pull off, an arrogant, haunted and intermittently jealous professor who is in some ways the villain of the piece but still remains completely believeable, layered, likeable and human as a character. Casey Affleck also shows the promise he had as an a completely irritating character but in my experience everyone has a friend like him in their group. He always says the wrong thing at the wrong time, you hate him for it at the time but love him for it afterwards. The baseball glove scene is hilarious. Ben Affleck is also standout in some of his scenes as well. The biggest star of the piece though is the script. One of the best scripts to be passed through Hollywood ever I think. Damon and Affleck should really write more or even better do a sequel. Some of the dialogue is superb, Williams (the park scene after Damon has remarked on Williams' painting especially) and Damon both have some great lines. Top this off with now classic scenes ('How do you like them apples!' 'It's not your fault') and a brilliant human story makes for an undeniable stonewall classic movie for me. If you haven't seen it make sure you track it down because it is like Will Hunting made this movie himself. It's that good.

Even though I should be able to see this as just a film without considering any attachment to its conception, it's incredibly difficult for me to see it as anything other than a self-serving pet project.

As we all know at this point, Matt Damon and Ben Affleck co-wrote the script and each play leading roles. Damon's character isn't so much an interesting person as he is a fantasy archetype for an actor. His character's brilliance is reasonably explained as unexplainable, but his ability to end arguments and destroy people's self-confidence is fun until we're supposed to see the damage that helped temper his affectations. If you can ignore this, you'll probably love the movie, if not... well, when the movie is named after the protagonist and you don't go with him, you're in a lot of trouble.

However, this isn't to say that the movie is bad or poorly constructed; though Williams' character utilizes some bizarre and probably inadvisable psychological techniques, his quiet moments and monologues cut right through you. His bickering with the oppressive prickishness of Skarsgaard form most of the film's most satisfying moments. Affleck's asides with his younger brother feel more like filler when they're not obviously trying to foreshadow the film's conclusion.

Even though it's problematic on the whole, and it definitely feels like a pet project, it's a damn good one.

"Some people can never believe in themselves until someone believes in them."

       Outstanding.  Prominent.  Striking.  Dramatic.  Riveting.  Gripping.  Absorbing.  Charasmatic.  Director Gus Van Sant's (Elephant) Award-Winning drama is a complete homerun.  Penned by both Matt Damon and Ben Affleck, this touching drama was a true inspiration to watch, a late 90's gem of a film that was hailed by audiences and critics alike.  A tender, sensative and atmospheric film that had me glued to the screen throughout.  A melodic, stoic and swift drama that tells a truly original, marvelously Inspirational and touching tale of the power of believing in one's self.  It's very moving from beginning to end, a film that has minimal flaw, brilliant direction and strong character development.  It's fresh and flat-magnificent, dramatic filmmaking at it's very best, a philosophical symphony of deeply dedicated performances and storytelling.  It's one thing to know that you have a gift, but to utilize and to use that gift to your advantage takes a strong will and the ability to believe in yourself, hence is the dilemma that Will Hunting faces in this film.  Good Will Hunting is fantastic, Affleck and Damon charged onto the scene with this highly-charged, straight-off-the-streets-of-Boston drama, this is the film that allowed both of these superstars to unleash their true talents in both acting and writing.  This is Gus Van Sant's finest hour, and in my opinion his very best film, it features beautiful storytelling, gorgeous cinematography and razor-sharp wit-filled dialogue and one-liners.  I loved it.
       The acting is spectacular.  Everyone involved ave it their all, and believe me, it shows.  Matt Damin is brilliant in easily the best performance of his career, he hits every end of the emotional spectrum in his performance as Will Hunting, Award-worthy in my opinion.  Ben Affleck adds the film's humor and does a great job throughout.  But for me it was Robin Williams who stole the show, this guy is a true legend in his own right and his performance in this film was one of the crowning achievements of his storied career.  He earned a Best Supporting Actor award for the performance, and he is just splendid to watch.  Cole Hauser and Minnie Driver were great as well.

GOOD WILL HUNTING is a warm, inviting, and very smart growing-up drama.  Matt Damon, Ben Affleck, Robin Williams, Stellan Skarsgaard, Minnie Driver, Casey Affleck, and Cole Hauser are a great ensemble and their accomplished work here is excellent.  Damon and Affleck are obviously smart guys, because the screenplay and story they wrote together is one that sheds light on the human condition and its internal clockwork, as well as people seeing a wonderful potential in another person and hoping they don't squander that potential.  Of course, as this film is set in Boston, there's plenty of realistic and crass dialogue between Will Hunting (Damon) and the people he knows.     

Gus Van Sant illuminates the story with an emphasis on the imperfections of the characters, because he knows those aspects of these people are what makes us care for them.  To be terse, GOOD WILL HUNTING tells the story of a troubled 20-year old orphan with a criminal record who also happens to be a mathematical genius in secret.  His friends don't know it yet, but as he works as a janitor as MIT he solves impossible problems the Math professor lays out for his students.  The story is set in motion when Hunting gets into another fight, and when the professor bails him out on two conditions: solve advanced mathematical formulas he and his colleagues have been studying for years, and to see a therapist weekly.  That therapist comes to be Sean (Williams), a humane professor.  

Seeing a film as multi-layered in meaning and resonating humanity, I feel that GOOD WILL HUNTING is a film that I can watch several years from now and see new things from a new perspective.  Not to mention from a new standpoint as to what the great dialogue means to me.  

Above all else, GOOD WILL HUNTING is a feel-good movie about what it means to grow up and to gain potential in one area of your life and to see as well as utilize that potential for your personal growth.  GOOD WILL HUNTING won two Oscars and was nominated for nine back in 1997.  It won for Best Original Screenplay and Best Supporting Actor, which are sufficient wins to earn.  It's such a suprise to look back and see that it didn't win more nominations than it did, though.  

In any case, GOOD WILL HUNTING is an incredible movie that pays testament to the human spirit, plain and simple.  Be ready for more Critiques and Opinions on Every Game and Movie I Can Get My Hands On!

It has taken me several years and many viewings of this film to finally be able to give it the review that I think it deserves, from my point of view. And the very fact this has been a laboured decision has probably been a good thing. Very few of my favourite films have been ones that I can sit down and review right away. They're usually so profound I have to experience them at different points in my life and at every turn, be amazed and vindicated by them.

Good Will Hunting is no different.

I want to start with my favourite aspect of the picture: the script. The script is by my definition completely sublime. It moves seamlessly from group dialogue, to one-on-one revelatory back and forth dialogue, to some of the all time best monologues I've ever heard. The monologue, so long associated with the diatribe of a supervillian in action films, is given new meaning here. The script manages to touch upon the many facets of human existence and reaction without sounding contrived or clichéd. If Damon and Affleck never write another script, never mind. This is one that defies all expectation. There is strong, believable character development throughout. At the moment I empathise with Will; young, ambitious, cocky and uncertain. I expect as I grow older, I will tend to empathise more with Shaun; experienced, intellectual and with an enduring 'down but not out' attitude.

This magnificent script is backed up by career defining performances. Matt Damon does a great job of the intelligent yet lost genius Will Hunting. We see that behind a defensive facade there is a fragile, talented individual making tentative steps into a potentially difficult adulthood. Ben Affleck is so good here as Will's best friend that I find it hard to believe he hasn't done anything as poignant since. As a blue-collar man with a simple philosophy (and one of the best monologues in the film, no less) he really defines and exceeds his archetype. Minnie Driver also performs wonderfully in an underrated role as Skylar - as with Affleck she is on such form that I can't believe she has not yet matched this performance. The real star turn here is of course Robin Williams, on startling form as a grieving psychologist. It's hard to describe how pivotal his role without giving away plot points. It suffices to say, it's an excellent study into character dimension.

With the script and performances discussed, it must also be said that the cinematography matches the intent of both perfectly. There is a nice mix of both shallow and deep focus shots, interesting and not overstated use of colour when contrasting both in and outdoor scenes and many other pleasing touches a more astute eye than mine will be able to identify. The film is also underpinned by a moving never obtrusive soundtrack; I was delighted to hear Elliott Smith featuring no less than three times.

To summarise without drifting into unending hyperbole, yes this film require some suspension of disbelief. If you are particularly gifted in the field that Will is purported to be a genius in, you may have a hard time. Even I identified some of the problems he faces as simplistic. I believe this course of action is taken to prevent alienation of the audience - a complex discussion of the intricacies of advanced mathematics would stiffen the pace and be besides the point. The film is about the journey of the protagonist; how a precarious genius might perceive the world around him or her in such a different way as to make social interaction difficult. It paints such a great picture that I feel that here is an underrated film that should be rendered 'classic' by the passage of time.

Here's hoping! 9.2/10

Will Hunting, as much of a mathematical genius as he may be, instead spends his time as a janitor at MIT and hangs out with his bar buddies in South Boston. His mathematical affinity truly shows when he solves an equation that stumps everybody else. Even though he's been getting in trouble with the law, he is released from jail on two conditions: work with the mathematics professor and see a counselor. Will is initially reluctant but gradually begins to discover his potential.

This film, in many ways, is unexpected, which is truly a breath of fresh air. Considering this is Ben Affleck's and Matt Damon's debut screenplay, they've done an impressive job with developing a deep but emotionally resonant script that packs some memorable dialogue. Gus Van Sant's direction is positively restrained, allowing the story to tell itself and thus lending the film more of an impact. The acting from the ensemble is great, especially with an incredible dramatic performance from Robin Williams. Beautiful music works crisply amongst the realistic photography. All the while, it has a great sense of humor, really hits the nail emotionally, and exudes an intelligence much like its protagonist's.

Yes, the storyline is average and predictable. Thankfully, though, the movie opts for realism over sentiment. Granted, it may have more of the feel of a psychoanalytic study than an actual film and some situations are contrived, but the film still endures to this day.

(fom The Watermark, 01/17/98)
	A sweet and moving film full of engaging characters, intelligent themes, and some of the best dialogue I've heard all year. Quite a surprise considering my expectations were somewhat low. Two of the actors, Damon and Affleck, also penned the script, and I was prepared for a cute little ego trip by two self-absorbed young actors. Not quite!
	Bostonian Will Hunting (Damon) and his underachiever friends, including Affleck, are resigned to their lives not amounting to much. But Damon has a problem: he's a genius, especially at math. When his talents are discovered by an MIT professor, he is allowed to join an award-winning research group - on the condition that he must go to therapy. Enter psychologist Williams who sees Damon's potential and must try to break through all the objective knowledge and get to the heart of his subject. And, yes, maybe learn a thing or two about himself in the process.
	This doesn't sound like anything that we haven't seen before in psychiatrist-patient films, but the unconventional approach and the genuineness of the performances propel this film to a higher level. Damon is sexy and likable even though his character has a gigantic chip on his shoulder. Affleck is carving a good niche for himself as the butch-yet-sensitive straight guy, who in this case wants his buddy to amount to something. Williams is wonderful in low-key mode in the bittersweet role of psychiatrist who can't get over his wife's death. Driver is an odd romantic match for Damon, but is completely captivating and believable. The ultimate message of the film is to honor your talents and heed your calling. Best of all, the elements of the story tie in together nicely while still avoiding a neatly packaged ending. Great acting and great writing rarely come from the same source, but I wouldn't be surprised to see Affleck and Damon as nominees and winners on Oscar night for Best Original Screenplay. QUEER QUOTIENT: Openly gay director Gus Van Sant (My Own Private Idaho, To Die For) obviously knows that his leading men are what will sell the picture. Thus, we get lots of lingering close-ups that let us luxuriously stroll across every inch of Damon's and Affleck's faces. Never has hetero been so well packaged for gay viewers. Thanks, Gus!

POST-REVIEW 05/06/10: I was right about the Oscar for screenplay! But the real surprise for me was Robin Williams' Oscar win. While I'm happy his talents finally earned him a gold statue, I still have to 'deduct points' from his performance and the film for his really uneven and often just-plain-wrong Boston accent. I'd rather they have just nixed the dialect altogether. It is not unusual for an educated professor/lecturer to acquire a Standard Midwestern dialect. Forgive my nit-pickiness, but I'm native Bostonian, and a dialect actor. : )

It took me almost 13 years from this movie's release to see it, and it was on cable, so I still haven't seen the theatrical version, but what a story/movie!  
And to think this was the start for Ben Affleck and Matt Damon, They hit a grand slam with this wonderful piece of work. Their success has that followed is no surprise.

This movie has it all, great acting, great writing, and great music, (Download Miss Misery by Elliot Smith it's in the movie) I loved the overall message in this film, It inspires me to try and reach for my dreams and punch adversity in the face, the characters were three dimensional and played very well by the people who played them, Robin Williams was very good in this film as well, he had a beard so its a good Robin Williams performance (Clean Shaven=bad movie) and the screenplay that Matt Damon and Ben Affleck wrote was tremendous and very unique. credit also goes to Gus Van Sant, who directed this film, great job done by all.

The only thing i knew about this movie before i saw it was that it had a lot of swear words in it. I don't really care to see movies I Don't know much about but I decided to give this one a try none the less.

To sum it up in a few words, I was Blown away.

From the acting to The Oscar winning screenplay this movie will touch you in a truly unique way. The movie starts of with Will Hunting (Matt Damon) going through is ordinary day to day life, which is filled with hanging round with his buddies, his part time job as a janitor and brutally beating up jerks. Although is high intelligence is apparent and shown through all this you can't help but wonder whats really wrong with this troubled genius. So after the Math professor of the collage catches him solving some the impossible sums he set for his class, he decides to bail him out from prison (kicking a cop in the crouch will get you there pretty quickly no matter how smart you are). So Will is bailed only under certain conditions which are that he must attained a weekly math class with the professor and meet a psychiatrist twice a week. Although the math classes are working out well, Will is convinced the does not need a psychiatrist and makes sure that all best possible options turn tale and head out the door. Thus the professor his forced to go to his former collage room-mate for help. This is where me meet Robin Williams in his Oscar winning role of a troubled psychiatric with his own troubled past.

This is where the movie lingers on and has we try do go deeper into Will thoughts we find more and more about the other people in his life whom he seems to have a profound effect on. Something people will notice is how Will's problems in his life are not so much different than ours and with Gus Van Sant's brilliantly simply direction it is shown with more heart than you can handle. As Will goes through problems with his love life, his past and what his future hold for him, we realize his life his a potential that all our lives should be. Apart from this each character is superbly distinguished as each play a different role in Will's life which is one of the many fine touches of the screenplay. This movie is almost all dialogue and the dialogue is pretty heavy most times thus not making it appealing to everyone's taste (which movie really is) but I highly recommend it as it one of the few movies that by the end of it you'll either smile or cry because you will look back at your life in truly different way.

I really liked this so much
Gus Van Sant made every scene so intriguing and the actors interacting with one another was pretty damn riveting
Matt Damon, Robin Williams and Stella Skarsgard are all so terrific
Damon playing a mathematical genius who doesn't see the extent of his talent is very misguided, introverted, and detached
Williams shows him the way to heal and help recognize his own abilities
I actually didn't mind Minnie Driver coming into the picture either, she's not the same usual love interest like in other movies, she's willing to take the risk and dive in
I love that I wasn't bored throughout this whole thing
sure there are two scenes with powerful drama but those moments in the film really project from the characters onto the viewer, it made the realism so much more potent
I got teary-eyed during the end of the 3rd act I wont lie
considering Will is from Boston and he appears to live a more lackluster lifestyle he still owes it to everyone even his friends to take an opportunity and make something out of it
even a so-called "smarty pants" has that inner rage and venting to hide, he can still be afraid of what he goes through with
'Good Will Hunting' is worth your time and I'm glad I had the time to sit down for it
